DOC.HEAD: 24 Top Communists To Go on Trial for Genocide
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-four top Communist officials who backed the late dictator Nicolae Ceausescu's order to shoot at demonstrators will go on trial for genocide, the Rompres news agency reported. The defendants allegedly took part in two Politburo meetings called by Ceausescu on December 17 and December 21, when the dictator ordered the army and security forces to open fire on demonstrators demanding his ouster, the report said Friday. At least 1,033 people died in the revolution that toppled Ceausescu and ended Communist rule in Romania. Ceausescu and his wife, Elena, were executed on Christmas Day. The defendants, scheduled to appear in court July 21, will include former Premier Constantin Dascalescu, former Parliament Speaker Nicolae Giosan and former Foreign Minister Ioan Totu, Rompres said.

DOC.HEAD: Biologist Leads Police to Store Selling Rare Animal Skins
DOC.TEXT: An angry biologist led authorities to a cache of rare armadillo, tiger and anaconda skins being sold illegally in a perfume shop, government officials said. The skins came from animals killed illegally in the protected Venezuelan jungles, the Environment Ministry said Friday. It said it seized the skins. Biologist Henry Garcia reported the Caracas store to authorities after seeing the skins there, the government news service Venpres said. Killing rare animals for their skins, though illegal, is a thriving and profitable business in Venezuela. The skins are often exported to make expensive clothes, handbags and shoes. Authorities say the hunters are endangering the wildlife of the Amazon jungle.

DOC.HEAD: Zsa Zsa Paying Debt to Society With Celebrity Auction
DOC.TEXT: Zsa Zsa Gabor peddled pedigreed animals, classy clothes and celebrity souvenirs Friday at a celebrity auction that she organized as penance for slapping a policeman. The celebrity guest list included entertainers Valerie Harper, Sally Struthers, Michelle Phillips, Cesar Romero, Esther Williams and comedian Fred Travalena. The actress, dressed in a Christian Dior outfit, shrugged off a judge's order that her auction not count as community service time for her conviction. Miss Gabor said she learned from her celebrated trial that ``You can't fight city hall'' but that the auction at the Beverly Hilton hotel was something good that came out of the episode. Proceeds _ hopes ran around $60,000 _ from the affair were to go to the Low Income Elderly United-Community Assistance Program, which operates a shelter for homeless mothers in the beach community of Venice. Miss Gabor was ordered to work for the shelter to fulfill community service provisions of her sentence for slapping Beverly Hills police Officer Paul Kramer on June 14, 1989. Municipal Judge Charles G. Rubin, who sentenced her, ruled that Miss Gabor must actually work at the shelter. He also increased her community service when she tried to tell the court about all the time she'd spent planning the auction. Auction fare included pedigreed dogs, cats and a horse; gowns by big-name designers like Bob Mackie; and such celebrity-donated bric-a-brac as drinking glasses from Bob Hope and some of Miss Gabor's old movie memorabilia. Her publicists said Miss Gabor donated $30,000 worth of jewelry and designer dresses. Former husband Barron Hilton donated one week for two at the Hilton Hawaiian village. Sidney Sheldon donated an autographed copy of his book, ``The Sands of Time'' and ``Phantom of the Opera'' star Robert Guillaume donated four tickets and a backstage pass to the popular musical play. The actress was sentenced to 120 hours of community service, three days in jail and ordered to pay court costs and fines totaling more than $12,000. The jail term has been stayed while she appeals her conviction.

DOC.HEAD: Elephants That Swam Across The Sea To Singapore Captured
DOC.TEXT: Trackers have captured three wild elephants who swam a mile from the Malaysian jungle to an island used by Singapore for military training, a newspaper said today. The male elephants were captured Thursday after Malaysian National Park and Wildlife trackers used tranquilizer guns to subdue them, the New Straits Times daily reported from Johore Bahru, 180 miles south of Kuala Lumpur. The elephants, found on uninhabited Tekong island last week, had left a trail of uprooted trees and flattened grass. Singapore, which controls the island, trains its armed forces there. The elephants are to be sent back to the Malaysian jungle in a few days, said Bernard Harrison, executive director of the Singapore Zoological Gardens. There are about 400 elephants in Malaysia. By law they cannot be hunted or captured without permission.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Airplane Hijacked, Lands Near Stockholm Early Saturday
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet airliner with 121 people aboard was hijacked by a teen-age runaway carrying a fake grenade and forced to land at an airport north of Stockholm early Saturday, police said. No one was hurt in the hijacking and the 17-year-old Soviet surrendered to authorities after the plane landed, police said. According to police statements, the young man had said that he had decided to escape the Soviet Union after he was thrown out from his parents' home. The young man's identity was not given. ``But he is not from one of the Baltic countries,'' said Malin Engstedt, chief press secretary of the Swedish Board of Civil Aviation. One police officer at the airport said the hijacker was an ethnic Russian. The three-engine Aeroflot plane was carrying 114 passengers and a seven-member crew from Minsk to Murmansk when it was hijacked and flown to Arlanda international airport, 25 miles north of Stockholm, the Swedish capital. The police searched the plane for explosives but did not find any. Swedish radio and the national news agency TT said the plane would return to the Soviet Union later Saturday, but the hijacker would remain for questioning. The last time a hijacked plane landed at Arlanda was in 1977. That time the aircraft also came from the Soviet union.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Remove Short-Range Nuclear Missiles
DOC.TEXT: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, responding to concerns that short-range nuclear missiles could leak plutonium, is ordering Air Force bombers to stop carrying older missiles until safety studies are completed. Cheney said in a statement Friday he was taking the step as ``a precaution.'' The directors of three U.S. nuclear weapons laboratories called for the withdrawal of the weapons during congressional testimony last month. They suggested there was a remote possibility the weapons could leak plutonium in an accident. The missiles are known as the Short-Range Attack Missile-A, or SRAM-As, and are carried aboard the nation's 372 deployed B-52, B-1B and FB-111 bombers. The Air Force has said that 1,500 of the weapons were produced between 1971 and 1975, but the current number deployed is classified. Sen. James Exon, D-Neb., chairman of the Armed Services strategic forces subcommittee, which heard the lab directors' testimony, agreed with the move. ``There was really nothing else the secretary could do,'' said Exon, who was interviewed on Cable News Network. Cheney's statement said the weapons would not be placed on board bombers on ``ground alert,'' the warplanes that are loaded with weapons, fueled, and ready to fly to war, if necessary, within minutes. The number of aircraft on such alert is classified. The weapons will be removed from the bombers pending the outcome of Air Force and Energy Department safety studies, expected to be completed this summer, the Pentagon statement said. The Energy Department is in charge of nuclear weapons. Cheney decided to remove the weapons after discussions with Energy Secretary James Watkins, the directors of the three laboratories and after receiving ``additional information'' about the SRAM-A, the statement said. It did not elaborate on what that information might have been. The SRAM-A is not the only nuclear weapon carried by bombers. The planes also carry a complement of longer-range nuclear missiles and free-fall bombs. A new model short-range missile designated SRAM-2 is under development for deployment in 1993. The 14-foot long SRAM-A is an air-to-surface missile armed with the W-69 nuclear warhead with an estimated explosive yield equivalent to 170,000 tons of TNT, which is 11 to 13 times the power of the bomb that destroyed Hiroshima in 1945. Some nuclear specialists have suggested it would be used against targets that threatened the bombers themselves, such as radar stations, fighter bases and antiaircraft missile sites, up to 100 miles away. The safety of the missile warhead was reviewed in 1989, and because of that review, some procedures for handling the weapons were modified. ``The laboratories have initiated new analyses. Until those analyses are complete, I believe it is prudent to take this action,'' the statement quoted Cheney as saying. ``The SRAM-A poses no safety hazards to the public.'' House Speaker Tom Foley, D-Wash., called the move ``correct and prudent.'' ``The international strategic conditions have changed dramatically in the last year as well, and we're not in the same condition of need for as widespread an alert status as was previously the case,'' he added. In their testimony May 23, the three laboratory directors said the missile might be vulnerable to an accidental explosion of the missile fuel that could disperse the highly toxic plutonium of the weapon. An accident, such as a fire or crash, could not detonate the plutonium, they said. The directors were John Nuckolls of the Lawrence Livermore National Laboratory in California, Sigfried Hecker of the Los Alamos National Laboratory in New Mexico and Albert Narath of Sandia National Laboratories in New Mexico. The withdrawal of the SRAM-A follows Cheney's disclosure in late May that a safety problem existed with U.S. nuclear artillery shells in Europe, but that it had been fixed and a risk of accidental nuclear explosions never materialized.

DOC.HEAD: Nevada Chief Justice Picked in Coin Toss
DOC.TEXT: Justice John Mowbray called heads and won a coin toss to get the job of chief justice of the Nevada Supreme Court for the next two years. The chief's job is rotated every two years to a justice with two years left in a six-year term. Mowbray and Justice Charles Springer both were elected to their current terms in 1986, so a coin toss was needed. Nevada's constitution prescribes the practice. ``There's probably not another state in the territory that does it this way,'' said Mowbray, 71. Cliff Young, who will complete a two-year term as chief justice in December, tossed a 50-cent piece in the air and told Mowbray and Springer to call it.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Robert Bork isn't entirely dejected about the notoriety over his unsuccessful bid for the U.S. Supreme Court. He just wishes people would stop recognizing him as C. Everett Koop. Both Bork and the former U.S. surgeon general sport beards _ Bork a unique goatee and Koop a seaman's style. Bork said Friday he thinks it's nice that ``people now recognize me wherever I go.'' But they're often confused about just why he's famous. He recalled at a meeting of Texas lawyers that a woman came up to him in a store and said, `` `Sir, we are heeding your warnings.' '' Confused, Bork asked her what warnings she was referring to. The woman replied, ` ``Well, you're the surgeon general, aren't you?' '' Bork was smoking a cigarette at the time. Koop waged war against tobacco use while surgeon general. Bork, a former federal appeals judge, went to work for a conservative think tank after the Senate in 1987 refused to confirm his nomination for the Supreme Court.

Actor John Cusack, who starred in the teen-age love movie ``Say Anything,'' can't slip behind a wheel for 90 days and must pay an $876 fine for driving drunk and crashing his rented Jeep into a car. Cusack, 23, who also appeared in the film ``The Sure Thing,'' pleaded no contest to a first-time misdemeanor charge of driving under the influence of alcohol. He sent his lawyer to the sentencing Friday and didn't appear in court, prosecutor Greg Lawler said. Cusack's sentence was standard for the charge in California on a first offense, Lawler said. Authorities said Cusack's blood alcohol level was .17 percent, more than twice the state's legal limit of .08, after the Feb. 23 collision in West Hollywood. Neither Cusack nor the other driver was hurt.

William Bennett, the nation's top drug warrior, admits he was a bit of a wimp in his youth. Bennett confessed Friday to his Williams College classmates at their 25th reunion that he was a frightened freshman. ``I was scared to death when I got here,'' Bennett said. ``I called my mother and said, `Maybe I should have gone to Holy Cross.' She said, `Stick it out.''' Bennett, who majored in philosophy at Williams, later got a Ph.D. in the same subject from the University of Texas and a law degree from Harvard. He became U.S. education secretary in 1985 and President Bush's drug czar in 1989. He said his days in college taught him ``the human experience is deeper than the shifting political experience.''

H. Ross Perot, the billionaire Texas businessman who says being a Boy Scout put him on the path of success, was honored with the Award for Courage of the Boy Scouts of America. The citation, presented at a Pierre Hotel luncheon Friday attended by luminaries of the business and entertainment worlds, lauded Perot as a person whose life demonstrates the ideals of scouting ``with outstanding courage and striking motivation.'' Perot formed Perot Systems in 1988 after General Motors paid him an additional $700 million for his stock in the company and to remove the outspoken businessman from the board of directors. Perot had gained a GM seat after he had sold his company, EDS, to GM in 1984. Perot has contributed millions of dollars to the Boy Scouts.

Former variety-show host Merv Griffin, who created and produces ``Wheel of Fortune,'' says the game show is considering whether to stop giving furs away to contestants. Griffin encountered a handful of animal rights activists demonstrating outside a radio station where he appeared on a call-in show Friday. The members of People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals held a banner saying ``Wheel of Torture'' and chanted, ``Buy a vowel, not a fur.'' Griffin, in his limousine, did not stop to talk with the demonstrators. But he said afterwards he had asked the game show's management to reconsider the practice of giving away furs. He said a decision should be reached soon. But Griffin also questioned whether there aren't more important issues. ``I just don't know where it is in the scheme of things,'' Griffin said. ``I'm really focused in other directions. There are major diseases we are all contending with and there are all the homeless, and there are the ecological problems on the planet.'' Griffin was host of ``The Merv Griffin Show'' for 23 years until 1986.

Exiled South African singer Miriam Makeba will return home Sunday for the first time in 30 years. A spokesman for the South African Musicians' Alliance confirmed the visit by Ms. Makeba, and said she would not be performing. Ms. Makeba plans to see family and friends and visit the grave of her mother who died when she was in exile. Ms. Makeba, 58, left South Africa in 1960 after touring abroad. She has lived in the United States, Guinea, Belgium and is now a resident of France. South Africa's government-run radio and television banned her music from 1976 until last year after she spoke out against apartheid. In 1987 she performed with singer Paul Simon on his ``Graceland'' tour.

DOC.HEAD: Birthday Surprise: 800-Mile Trip for Dinner
DOC.TEXT: When Peter Rowe decided to take his wife out to dinner for her birthday, he took her way out _ 800 miles away. Not until she was over New York City on a chartered flight from Michigan on Thursday night did Pat Rowe have the slightest idea where she'd be celebrating her 40th birthday. At that point she shouted to her husband, ``We're going to New Haven to have dinner at Leon's!'' Leon's had been Pat's favorite restaurant when she and her husband lived in Madison, Conn., until 1977. Then they moved to Bloomfield Hills, Mich., about 800 miles away. When the time came to give her a special surprise, Peter decided the party would be at Leon's. He chartered a jet, got six friends from Michigan to go along, rented a limousine at Tweed-New Haven Airport and arranged for two of Pat's sisters and their husbands to meet them at the restaurant. ``It's wonderful,'' Pat said. ``It certainly makes my birthday something to remember.''

DOC.HEAD: Bush Pledges that Germany Will Not Threaten the Soviet Union
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is pledging that a united Germany will not threaten the Soviet Union but says he and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl have ``no specific formula'' to ensure that. Bush and Kohl, after meeting Friday evening, continued to insist on keeping a unified Germany in NATO _ something the Soviet Union strongly opposes _ and Bush said they talked about ``an expanded role'' for the Western alliance in the future. ``We also agree that the Soviets have understandable interests in all of this but we did not try to fashion some compromise at this juncture,'' he said in the Rose Garden where he and Kohl took questions from reporters. Bush said further consultations will take place before and after the July meeting of allied leaders in London. ``We will be talking to the other leaders in NATO about how we lay to rest any concerns that the Soviets might have, by having an expanded role that certainly will be seen to be as unthreatening to the Soviet Union. But we had no formula that we agreed on,'' he said of his two-hour meeting with Kohl. Bush and Kohl dined at the White House after the president returned from a two-day politicking trip to the Midwest. Bush then flew to Camp David, Md., for a weekend at the presidential countryside retreat. Joining them for dinner were Vice President Dan Quayle, National Security adviser Brent Scowcroft and Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Baker flew back Friday from Scotland where he met with foreign ministers of 15 allied countries on future security for Europe and the German question. Baker said in Scotland he had found the Soviet attitude about enrolling a unified Germany in NATO ``much more encouraging'' since Bush's summit talks with Gorbachev last week in Washington. ``A united Germany in NATO will not be threatening to the Soviet Union,'' Bush vowed Friday night. ``A U.S. presence will not be threatening to the Soviet Union. So we've just got to keep on making our case.'' Kohl said having Germany in NATO ``is of essential importance.'' ``Any singling out and neutralization always means isolation,'' he added, noting that Germany's isolation during the 1920s led to the chain of events that eventually saw the country divided in half after World War II. As to the Soviet objections that having Germany in NATO would threaten the Soviet security, Kohl held out hope that the roadblocks could be solved so that unification talks could be complete by the fall. ``I never expected this important question could be solved overnight,'' he said. ``We as Germans as a matter of course ... also are going to bear in mind Soviet security,'' Kohl vowed. Bush, who previously called for NATO to completely rethink its military and political strategy, said that such a statementwas unlikely to come out of the July NATO summit in London. However, he said the allies hope to ``more clearly define what we're talking about'' on the matter of an expanded NATO. He said the meeting would more likely produce ``a common direction'' for that concept, but not one with ``every `t' crossed and every `i' dotted.'' Earlier, between stops in the Midwest where he stumped for gubernatorial and Senate candidates, Bush said he is considering breaking off talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization after the ``sheer terror'' of a thwarted Palestinian attack on an Israeli beach. In Washington, a senior administration official said he expected a 30-day suspension of the talks that began in December 1988, but cautioned no final decision had been made. Bush called on PLO leader Yasser Arafat to publicly renounce the attack and suggested the continuation of U.S.-PLO contacts depended on Arafat's response.

DOC.HEAD: Mitchell Threatens to Crack Down, Lengthen Work Week for Senate
DOC.TEXT: Senate Majority Leader George J. Mitchell says it's no more Mr. Nice Guy. Senators will have to start putting their elected noses to the grindstone. Frustrated after a week in which no action was completed on the four bills on his menu, Mitchell threatened Friday to crack the whip. In keeping with the Senate's leaning toward abundant etiquette, Mitchell's warning came after consulting his Republican and Democratic colleagues. Mitchell said he's thinking about putting a stop to four-day weekends and shortening the four-week August recess so senators can tend to legislative basics like the budget and defense and farm legislation. The $98,000-a-year senators may also face the prospect of voting in the morning and burning the midnight oil more than one night a week, Mitchell said. Thursday is the only regular day for late-night sessions. He didn't mention having the sergeant-at-arms make midnight arrests and physically carry reluctant lawmakers to the Senate floor. Democrats under former Majority Leader Robert C. Byrd of West Virginia resorted to that tactic in February 1988. ``We're just reaching the point where it is very, very difficult to move forward on any piece of legislation,'' Mitchell said, adding he was particularly perturbed at a higher-than-usual absentee rate. Senators had been asking him to put off important votes while they went to graduations, to Czechoslovakia to monitor elections, or make their regular weekend visits to home states to meet with voters, raise money or electioneer. ``Obviously that circumstance cannot continue,'' Mitchell said. ``We all have an obligation to conduct the public business.'' Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., who once had Mitchell's job, said forcing a senator to the floor is like leading a horse to water. ``It doesn't mean we're going to do anything in that time,'' Dole said, explaining that Republicans don't share Mitchell's sense of urgency about some of the legislation. But at least one Republican, Sen. Nancy Kassebaum, R-Kan., said she was disappointed so few senators were around to vote on an amendment she was seeking to protect the general aviation industry. Dole also joked that the public might like having their lawmakers as far away from Washington as possible. ``We can't do anything to them while we're home,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Barry, Jackson to Meet to Discuss Mayor's Future
DOC.TEXT: Jesse Jackson wants Mayor Marion Barry to abandon his re-election bid and plans to discuss the mayor's political future this weekend during a break in Barry's cocaine and perjury trial, sources close to both men say. The talks will focus on Jackson's suggestion that Barry abandon his re-election plans, the sources said Friday, speaking on condition of anonymity. Jackson publicly encouraged Barry this week to announce he won't seek re-election in an attempt to spur plea bargaining talks that would resolve the mayor's criminal case, which is absorbing the capital city. On Friday, Barry spokeswoman Lurma Rackley said, ``There is no official plea bargaining under way and (Barry) has not made a decision on re-election plans.'' As for plea bargaining between prosecutors and Barry's defense lawyer, one top city official said no meetings had been set up but ``there is an ongoing dialogue between them.'' He said the situation was ``changing almost hourly.'' Barry has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge, and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about drug use. U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens wants any bargain to include a guilty plea on a felony charge. But the mayor is only willing to consider pleading to misdemeanors, law enforcement and city government sources say. Under federal sentencing guidelines, pleading guilty to a perjury charge would guarantee that Barry would spend time behind bars. Once he entered jail, he would be forced to give up the job he has held since 1979. The first week of Barry's trial has been taken up with jury selection, which is expected to continue all of next week. A jury will be seated June 18, U.S. District Court Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson said. The jury pool for Barry's trial now stands at 48. Twelve additional jurors were sent into the pool Friday and one already in the pool was excused. Judge Jackson says he plans to go through the remainder of the 250 people who have filled out questionnaires for the Barry trial. So far, the judge and the lawyers in the case have examined some 90 questionnaires.

DOC.HEAD: East German Wants to Make Reparations to Jews, But Could Cost Billions
DOC.TEXT: East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere wants to negotiate compensation for Jewish victims of the Nazi Holocaust, but his country may not be able to afford the probably astronomical cost. De Maiziere plans to meet Sunday in New York with representatives of the Conference on Jewish Material Claims, set up in 1951 to negotiate reparations for the 6 million Jews killed by the Nazis, an official of the World Jewish Congress said. The East German compensation could reach into the billions of dollars, but might be limited by the government's financial problems. East Germany, which ended nearly 45 years of communist rule in the country's first free elections last March, is reuniting with West Germany. The economic union of the two countries is scheduled to be completed by July with West Germany expected to assume many of its financially strapped neighbor's liabilities. Under a 1952 agreement, West Germany has paid more than $40 billion in reparations to Israel, to Jewish groups and to individual claimants. The Luxembourg Agreement called for West Germany to pay two-thirds of the total compensation. But East Germany's communist leaders, citing the systematic persecution of communists by the Nazis, refused to recognize any responsibility or to pay the remaining third of the claims. After World War II, East Germany was dominated by the Soviet Union, which had lost at least 20 million lives to the Nazis. One of the first acts of the new democratic East German parliament was to concede a share of the blame for the Nazis' deeds. In a letter to WJC President Edgar Bronfman, de Maiziere said he would be ``grateful if ... you were to initiate soonest conversations'' with East German government experts ``in which a settlement of the Jewish claims would be agreed on within the framework of our possibilities.'' A copy of the letter was made available to The Associated Press. De Maiziere's request to start negotiations ``is historic in that it fulfills a pledge of the new government to assume moral responsibility for the crimes of the Germans against the Jews,'' said WJC Executive Director Elan Steinberg. He said the meeting Sunday between de Maiziere and the claims body would be preliminary and would set up future negotiating sessions. De Maiziere heads for Washington Monday to meet with President Bush _ the first White House meeting between an East German prime minister and a U.S. president.

DOC.HEAD: Pickets Dismantled, Strike Ends in Maryland and Five Other States
DOC.TEXT: Under court order, striking railroad workers in six states dismantled their pickets and went back to work for CSX Transportation Inc. U.S. District Court Judge John R. Hargrove on Friday issued a 10-day temporary restraining order forcing the workers to end their one-day walkout. ``The pickets came down between 11 a.m. and 2:30 or so and everything is resumed,'' CSX spokesman Lindsay Leckie said Friday night. The International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers organized the strike Thursday morning over the indefinite layoff of 11 crane operators in Cumberland. ``We are complying with the judge's order. We're not going to defy a federal judge,'' said George Laitila, a regional IBEW representative. Laitila said thousands of union workers had honored picket lines in Maryland, West Virginia, Pennsylvania, Delaware, Indiana and Ohio. Leckie said it was impossible to know how many people refused to cross the picket line. The walkout caused minor delays along 5,500 miles of the former Baltimore & Ohio Railroad system, which runs through parts of Indiana, Illinois, Ohio, Pennsylvania, Maryland and West Virginia. About 7,400 riders on two Maryland commuter lines were forced to find other ways to and from their jobs in Washington, D.C., on Friday. Another CSX spokesman, Lloyd D. Lewis, said the judge decided ``this was a minor dispute that did not allow the union to strike.'' Laitila disagreed, and said the union would present its case in a federal court hearing. The union contended that CSX violated an agreement with the electrical workers when it announced a furlough last week of 45 employees, including the crane operators, at a train yard in Cumberland, Md.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Hears Testimony on Possible Changes in Child Labor Laws
DOC.TEXT: A crackdown on child labor law violations could ruin work opportunities for youngsters, says a Texas businessman facing fines from a nationwide Labor Department sweep. Donald Farrell told the House Government Operations employment and housing subcommittee on Friday that jobs like those he provides give youngsters, especially those from unstable homes, a chance to earn money, experience and self-respect. ``Please do not allow misguided idealism and governmental paternalism to close that door. They desperately need an alternative to the street corner and the dangers associated with that irresponsible lifestyle,'' Farrell said. Farrell's Dallas business is under investigation for allegedly letting nearly 300 children illegally sell newspaper subscriptions at night. Farrell faces $150,000 in fines for alleged violations uncovered in a nationwide Labor Department sweep in March. He was one of several business officials who testified as the panel continued hearings on protecting children in the workplace. Two high school students also testified, saying their grades had slipped because they were devoting too much time to their jobs. Christopher Randolph, a senior from Clifton Park, N.Y., said teen-agers were ``easy marks for exploitation.'' Congress is considering legislation to increase civil fines for child labor law violations from $1,000 a violation to $10,000. The legislation also would require jail terms for repeat and willful offenders. Along with congressional attention, the Labor Department has stepped up its enforcement. The nationwide sweep conducted in March uncovered 15,000 alleged violations. Federal agents followed with a one-day effort this week by visiting another 2,000 establishments.
DOC.HEAD: Organization Aims Effort at Tropical Diseases
DOC.TEXT: An international health organization has started a 10-year program to help developing companies control tropical diseases such as intestinal worms and malaria. International Medical Services for Health, based in Leesburg, Va., said Friday it is raising money from companies, individuals and foundations to help Third World countries solve their health problems. ``We know we can affect the lives of 500 million people by the year 2000,'' said Linda Pfeiffer, president of the nonprofit international health organization.'' More than 3 billion people _ half the world's population _ are afflicted by intestinal worms, malaria and schistosomiasis, she said. ``We can't do it for the whole world by the year 2000 ... but for this large part of the population we can contain it,'' she said in an interview. Officials of the organization were holding a two-day conference in Washington with representatives of nonprofit groups from 25 countries and public health experts to work on the project, called the Millennium Program. The conference was sponsored by an educational grant from SmithKline Beecham Pharmaceuticals, one of about 25 drug companies that contribute to the organization.
DOC.HEAD: Congressman Seeks Better Discipline For Physicians
DOC.TEXT: Congress should help in disciplining and weeding out bad physicians by making doctors more accountable to their state licensing boards, Rep. Ron Wyden says. The Oregon Democrat endorsed the recommendations of an inspector general's report, saying he'll introduce legislation to force federally supported peer review groups to give state medical boards information about their investigations of doctors. ``Too many incompetent physicians can slip through the disciplinary net and continue to inflict bad medical care on patients for extended periods of time,'' he said. The peer review organizations study complaints about physicians who receive money from Medicare. But little of that information is passed along to boards that license doctors and investigate complaints about their practices, witnesses told the House Small Business subcommittee on regulation. Richard Kusserow, inspector general for the Department of Health and Human Services, said the review organizations have lots of information about bad doctors but are unwilling to share much of it because they fear legal retribution.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Assaulted in Washington; Two Arrested
DOC.TEXT: A bruised Rep. Gerry Studds, D-Mass., thanked the quick action of passersby for saving him from more serious injury in a sidewalk attack. Investigators were seeking a motive in the case. Studds rested in his Provincetown, Mass., summer home today recovering from cuts and bruises inflicted by two men who beat him up on a Washington street corner early Friday. Four pedestrians saw the assault and chased away the attackers, but Studds had already been knocked down and beaten, said Steven Schwadron, a spokesman for the nine-term Democrat. ``The witnesses were really phenomenal,'' Schwadron said. ``What they did is what convinced the guys to flee.'' The passersby flagged down a U.S. Secret Service car that happened to be driving through the area. A short time later two uniformed agents arrested the suspects, who had blood on their hands and clothing. The Secret Service said the suspects later admitted to the beating. ``Gerry was mugged and beaten up pretty bad, but the bottom line is he's OK,'' Schwadron said. The attackers knocked Studds down, then punched and kicked him in the head and body while a third man egged them on early Friday, according to U.S. Attorney Jay B. Stephens. Thomas Carter, 18, of Gaithersburg, Md., and James Byrne, 19, of Silver Spring, Md., were charged in federal court Friday with assault on a member of Congress with resulting injury. The charge is a felony that carries penalties of up to 10 years in jail and a $10,000 fine upon conviction. A third suspect was released because he was not directly involved in the beating, said Secret Service Officer Kevin S. Porter, who took part in the arrest. In a sworn, written statement to the court, Porter quoted Carter as saying shortly after his arrest: ``It seemed like the thing to do at the time.'' Once in his cell, Carter was overheard saying, ``I beat up a congressman.'' Porter quoted Byrne as saying: ``I only hit the dude a couple of times.'' Studds, 53, is one of two members of Congress who has publicly stated that he is homosexual, but Schwadron said there was no indication that was a motive for the attack. ``There doesn't seem to have been any clear motive,'' Schwadron said. ``There was no robbery.'' The incident occurred at about 12:30 a.m. in the DuPont Circle neighborhood of Washington, a block from where Studds lives, according to Stevens. Studds' office said the congressman was returning home alone from dinner at a friend's house. He was treated at the scene by an ambulance crew, Allan Cramer, a Secret Service spokesman said. The attack apparently did not disrupt the congressman's schedule. Schwadron said Studds kept an appointment to meet a group of students from a Cape Cod high school on the Capitol steps Friday morning.

DOC.TEXT: The Associated Press reported erroneously June 8 that FBI investigators said Roderick James Ramsay, a former Army sergeant, received up to $5 million from East bloc countries for delivering secret NATO plans. Joe Navarro, the FBI agent who led the investigation, estimated that East bloc agents paid between $2.2 million and $5 million for information from a spy ring, and that Ramsay admitted receiving $20,000.

DOC.HEAD: New Gov't Policies Could Cause More Tension with Washington
DOC.TEXT: The hard-line policies toward Palestinians espoused by Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's new right-wing government could worsen already strained relations with the United States. Shamir formed his government Friday, breaking a deadlock that began March 15 when the governing coalition collapsed over Shamir's failure to endorse U.S. proposals for Israeli-Palestinian peace talks. The new government has pledged to expand settlements in the occupied lands and use harsh measures to quell the Arab uprising, both moves that could aggravate tensions with Washington. The government, which still needs parliamentary approval, has also ruled out talks with the Palestine Liberation Organization _ which Israel views as a terrorist group _ and any negotiations concerning the status of Jerusalem, which it considers ``Israel's eternal capital.'' Washington has pressed for Israeli-Palestinian talks and does not recognize Israel's annexation of Arab east Jerusalem. It has called settlements in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip obstacles to peace, and has called on the Israeli army to use restraint in supressing Palestinian protests. Shamir said Friday that his government's main goal would be to settle the influx of Soviet Jews, expected to total 150,000 this year. He called the immigration ``the most important issue we are facing today.'' The government also pledged to retain its May 1989 peace initiative promising Palestinians elections, but vowed to ``uproot the phenomenon of violence and disturbances'' _ a reference to the Palestinian uprising. Faisal Husseini, a leading pro-PLO activist in the occupied territories, said the new government will create ``more obstacles in the way of peace.'' ``I believe this government will try to crush the uprising, and the uprising will prove there is no way to crush it,'' he said. ``But the price will be high.'' The rival Labor Party called the new coalition ``a government whose principles and policies deviate from the interests of Israel and its citizens, the most anti-Israeli government that ever arose.'' Labor leader Shimon Peres predicted the coalition would be plagued by infighting, saying: ``Most of its time and energy will be spent in holding it together.'' Peres, Shamir's rival, tried for 35 days to form a Cabinet before surrendering the task to Shamir. Shamir telephoned President Chaim Herzog to report the formation of the government just hours before his 42-day mandate expired at sundown. A vote in the Knesset, or parliament, could be scheduled as early as Monday. In the new government, Shamir's Likud bloc will have full control for the first time since 1984. Close election results since then had forced Likud into power-sharing arrangements with the left-center Labor Party. The new coalition includes two nationalist parties, three religious ones, two one-man factions and a defector from Labor. Under the coalition agreement, Shamir would have 62 votes in the 120-member Knesset. But the coalition is shaky and divided, prone to pressures from some of the eight factions comprising it, notably two ultra-Orthodox parties. The two decisive votes came from the nationalist Moledet, or Homeland party, which promised to support the government but refused to join it. One nationalist party within the coalition got the freedom to vote as it wants on peace moves. According to officials in Shamir's office, key posts in the new Cabinet went to Likud hard-liners. The most controversial of the reported appointments appeared to be that of Ariel Sharon as minister of housing. Sharon was the architect of Israel's 1982 invasion of Lebanon and is a strong backer of Israel's settlement drive. Asked about moving Soviet Jews to the occupied territories, Sharon reiterated the government's stand that ``everyone can settle where he wants.'' The government's guidelines and the coalition agreement include many promises to meet demands of the small parties. These included legislation banning the sale of pork in line with religious commandments and increased observance of the Jewish Sabbath. Shamir dismissed claims that his government would be subject to religious coercion and far-right pressures. ``This government represents many circles in Israel,'' he said. ``It is a broad-based nationalistic government. It is not right-wing and not narrow.''

DOC.HEAD: List of Expected Cabinet Members in New Israeli Government
With PM-Israel
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of ministers expected to be named in Israel's new right-wing coalition government. Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, whose office provided the list, has not yet announced the makeup of the Cabinet. The new government also needs the approval of the Knesset, or parliament. All are members of Shamir's Likud Party, except as noted. _ Prime Minister: Yitzhak Shamir. _ Foreign Minister: David Levy. _ Defense Minister: Moshe Arens. _ Finance Minister: Yitzhak Modai. _ Housing Minister and head of a ministerial committee dealing with immigrant absorption: Ariel Sharon. _ Justice Minister: Dan Meridor _ Interior Minister: Arieh Deri, Shas Party. _ Police Minister: Ronnie Milo. _ Economy and Planning Minister: David Magen. _ Communications Minister: Rafael Pinhasi, Shas Party. _ Transportation Minister: Moshe Katzav. _ Tourism Minister: Gideon Patt. _ Health Minister, Ehud Olmert. _ Education Minister: Zevulun Hammer, National Religious Party. _ Religious Affairs Minister: Avner Shaki, National Religious Party. _ Science Minister: Unnamed, reserved for Tehihya Party. _ Agriculture Minister: Rafael Eitan, Tzomet Party. _ Labor and Social Welfare Minister: Unnamed, reserved for Aguda Israel. _ Industry and Trade Minister: Moshe Nissim. _ Absorption Minister: Yitzhak Peretz, independent, breakaway from Shas Party.

DOC.HEAD: With PM-Israel
Key Members of New Government
DOC.TEXT: Here are thumbnail sketches of four key members of the new right-wing Israeli coalition government. Cabinet posts have not been formally assigned and the new government will not be approved by the Knesset, or parliament, until at Monday at the earliest. _ Yitzhak Shamir, prime minister. The Polish-born Shamir, 74, has been premier off-and-on since 1983, most recently as head of the coalition that collapsed in March with the left-center Labor Party. He was co-leader of the Stern Gang, the most radical movement fighting for creation of the Jewish state. Later, he was an agent for the Mossad secret service. In politics, he climbled the ranks through loyalty to Likud founder and ex-Prime Minister Menachem Begin. He opposed giving up the Sinai Peninsula to make peace with Egypt and has resisted U.S.-proposed compromises for opening peace talks with Palestinians. _ Ariel Sharon, housing minister. Sharon is known for his hard-line views on keeping the occupied territories and halting the Palestinian uprising. Sharon, 62, also will head a powerful, special committee in charge of the wave of Soviet Jewish immigration to Israel. A native-born Israeli and former general, he was a hero in the 1967 and 1973 wars, but was blamed for leading Israel into the unpopular 1982 Lebanon war. In 1983, he was forced to step down as defense minister when an inquiry found him responsible for the massacre of hundreds of Palestinians in two Beirut refugee camps. The inquiry commission said Sharon should have realized what would happen if he let Israel's Christian militia allies enter the camps. _ Moshe Arens, defense minister. Arens was born in Lithuania but educated as an engineer in the United States. In Israel, he was a professor of aeronautical engineering and deputy director of the government-sponsored aircraft industry. Arens, 64, was ambassador to the United States in 1982-83 and defense minister in Shamir's government in 1983-84. As foreign minister in the most recent Cabinet, he often echoed Shamir's views and was the chief spokesman in the campaign to brand the PLO a terrorist organization. _ David Levy, foreign minister. Levy was born in Morocco and is the leading politician among Israel's Sephardis, or Jews of North African and Middle Eastern descent. Levy, 52, was a construction worker who entered politics through Israel's federation of labor unions. He has been immigration minister and in the latest Cabinet was vice premier and housing minister. Word that he might be foreign minister raised criticism because he does not speak English well, though he is fluent in French. He and Sharon are Shamir's chief rivals in Likud and have consistently pushed far-right positions.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Educator Begins Sixth Year in Captivity
DOC.TEXT: American educator Thomas Sutherland today began his sixth year as a hostage, and his wife and friends at the American University of Beirut gathered to mark the grim milestone and discuss his life and work. Since Sutherland was captured June 9, 1985, the only word on his condition has come from former hostages who were held with him. The pro-Iranian group that holds him, Islamic Jihad, has never issued a photograph of Sutherland as it has its other captives. Students and colleagues who gathered Friday to mark the anniversary of Sutherland's captivity recalled his commitment to the American University of Beirut. The Scottish-born, 59-year-old educator from Fort Collins, Colo., was dean of agriculture and food sciences at the school when he was kidnapped. ``People who have come out from where he is and who have been with him say that Tom speaks and thinks of AUB and wants to come back,'' said Sutherland's wife, Jean. ``The four things that mean the most to Tom ... are his home, his family, his work and his friends, and he found all four of those here in Beirut and at AUB,'' she said. She spoke at the lecture hall in the university's agriculture building. One of those attending was Elham Cicippio, the wife of American hostage Joseph Cicippio, who was the acting comptroller at the university. He was kidnapped Sept. 12, 1986. In addition to Sutherland and Cicippio, 14 other Westerners are missing in Lebanon. The longest held is Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, who was kidnapped March 16, 1985. Next to Anderson, Sutherland has been held the longest. Most of the hostages are held by pro-Iranian Shiite factions. Mrs. Sutherland still lives at the American University in Moslem west Beirut, continuing the work she and her husband were doing when he was abducted. ``Tom and I are ordinary people,'' she said Friday. ``We came here to do a job. The job is still to be done, and we're still doing it. She said what her husband is going through is ``only a reflection, a shadow of what the people in Lebanon'' have gone through in 15 years of civil war. ``We hope that ... when he comes out, it means reconciliation, it means that people are not divided, that people are on their way to work together in peace and harmony,'' she said. She and the students on pinned photographs of Sutherland to a board in the hall. The Sutherlands have three daughters: Ann, 32; Kit, 30; and Joan, 26. They all live and work in the United States. Former hostages have told Mrs. Sutherland that her husband's captors had given him a picture she placed in a newspaper of his only granddaughter, Simone, 3, who was born after his abduction. Sutherland was seized as he drove from the airport after arriving from the United States to attend the graduation of his students. Mrs. Sutherland told The Associated Press her husband had been hesitant about returning to Beirut because of the civil war and kidnappings. She recalled that in the last week before he returned to Beirut, an interviewer asked her husband whether he was afraid. ``He said, `If I'm going to be afraid, I'd better not be there.'''

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Defense Suffers Two Big Blows
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge rejected Manuel Noriega's claim that the United States has no jurisdiction to indict him on charges he trafficked drugs as Panama's leader. In a second blow Friday to Noriega's legal defense, a co-defendant in a parallel Tampa indictment named the ousted Panamanian dictator as a ``silent partner'' in a drug ring. In Miami, U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler rejected defense claims that Noriega had immunity for his actions and could not be prosecuted for activities outside the United States. In Tampa, Panamanian jeweler Enrique A. ``Kiki'' Pretelt admitted in a plea agreement that he helped launder drug proceeds with two convicted Tampa drug smugglers, according to a 10-page plea agreement. ``A fourth silent partner in their business was Gen. Manuel Noriega,'' the agreement said. Noriega, in prison outside of Miami, is accused in a February 1988 indictment of taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a way station for U.S.-bound drugs. Hoeveler ruled that the argument Noriega had ``sovereign immunity'' as head of state failed because the United States never recognized him in that role. ``Given the serious nature of the drug epidemic in this country, certainly the efforts of the U.S. to combat the problem by prosecuting conduct directed against itself cannot be subject to the protest of a foreign nation profiting at U.S. expense,'' the judge said. Noriega's lawyers also argued that the indictment should be dismissed because the U.S. invasion of Panama leading to Noriega's arrest was so bloody it should ``shock the conscience.'' Hoeveler rejected that argument too. ``Noriega's complaint is a challenge to the very morality of war itself,'' he said. ``This is a political question.'' Defense attorney Jon May said the rulings cannot be appealed until after the trial. Under the agreement accepted by U.S. District Judge William Castagna in Tampa, Pretelt promised to cooperate fully, testify and turn over any relevant documents to prosecutors. He also will forfeit $108,000. Pretelt, 47, acknowledged conspiring with Noriega to take bribes from the drug smugglers to help ferry $300 million worth of Colombian marijuana through Panama and hide the profits. The agreement said Noriega and the other partners received a commission every time Steven Michael Kalish deposited drug proceeds in Panamanian bank accounts. They were to receive $4 million, but Kalish was arrested before 200 tons of marijuana concealed in a shipment of plantain bananas was completed. The bananas were to be relabled in Panama to conceal their Colombian origin. Kalish has pleaded guilty to other drug charges and testified before a U.S. Senate subcommittee that the bribes were part of more than $4 million in cash, jewelry and airplanes his ring gave to Noriega and his associates. In return, Noriega gave Kalish a diplomatic passport, false Panamanian customs documents to disguise drug shipments from Colombia and provided armored car service to shuttle cash, according to the indictment. Defense attorney George Tragos said Pretelt, the lone co-defendant in the parallel drug indictment, obtained a ``great deal'' because prosecutors in Noriega's drug racketeering case in Miami want his cooperation. ``I think the biggest single incentive the government had for the plea agreement is the testimony about General Manuel Noriega,'' Tragos said. Pretelt pleaded guilty to two of his three drug counts, and will be sentenced to no more than 10 years in federal prison. Prosecutors will also recommend that immigration authorities not deport him to Panama if his testimony puts him in jeopardy. Sentencing is set for Aug. 16. Pretelt went underground soon after the U.S. invasion of Panama on Dec. 20 and surrendered Jan. 17. Noriega also fled, taking refuge for 10 days at a Vatican diplomatic compound before surrendering to FBI agents in Panama.

DOC.HEAD: Kevorkian Ordered Not to Aid People Seeking Use of Machine.
LaserPhoto DT4
DOC.TEXT: The inventor of a push-button device that lets people kill themselves painlessly says terminally ill people seeking his help will be distraught to learn he's under court orders not to use it. ``I'll tell them, `I'm sorry, I can't help you. It's illegal,''' said Dr. Jack Kevorkian, shaking his head after he was slapped with an injunction Friday that also barred him from helping people use any other means to commit suicide. ``It's the end of Dr. K. helping patients die,'' said Kevorkian, a 62-year-old retired pathologist who this week aided the suicide of a woman diagnosed a year ago with Alzheimer's disease. Judge Alice Gilbert of Oakland County Circuit Court ordered Kevorkian to stop using his machine until prosecutors decide whether to try him in the suicide Monday of Janet Adkins, 54, of Portland, Ore. Kevorkian hooked Adkins up to his suicide machine in his van, parked in a state park, and she pressed a button that triggered a flow of coma- and death-inducing drugs into her veins. Michigan law makes neither suicide nor doctor-assisted suicide a crime, and assistant prosecutor Michael Modelski said there were no immediate plans to prosecute. But the county prosecutor, state police and Michigan medical association are investigating the death of Adkins. ``Everything about this case points to irresponsibility,'' said Modelski, calling Kevorkian ``an Angel of Death.'' ``He sort of revels in the fact that he's sort of an outcast,'' Modelski said. Kevorkian said, ``I don't enjoy seeing people die.'' But ``the elderly are killing themselves by all kinds of violent means. They deserve options.'' He said two women in their 80s who heard about the Adkins case contacted him to offer their support for his device. ``They were weeping on the phone,'' the doctor said. ``They know that this option is available if they need it. Kevorkian said he probably won't appeal Gilbert's decision, which Modelski said is effective statewide. ``Since he's only licensed in Michigan, that should shut him down,'' Modelski said. The doctor, who acted as his own lawyer at the hearing, had asked the judge for a partial injunction which would allow use of his machine in ``a specific set of circumstances.'' He said he wanted time to set up a committee of specialists to establish a permanent ``planned death policy,'' and establish an ``obitorium,'' a clinic for the terminally ill who want medical help with suicide. ``Let me put together a small team, called the Untouchables,'' Kevorkian said. ``I guarantee, under my supervision, it would be incorruptible.'' Kevorkian's sister, Flora Holzheimer of Frankfurt, West Germany, testified that she spent last Saturday with her brother, Mrs. Adkins and Mrs. Adkins husband, Ronald. Holzheimer said that when she picked up Mrs. Adkins Monday for the suicide crusade: ``It was a sad affair. She had her bag in her hand, her husband straightened his tie ... they said their goodbyes.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Navy Officer Faces Trial For Rape Of Female Officer
DOC.TEXT: A U.S. Navy lieutenant faces trial next month for allegedly raping a female officer aboard an ammunition ship while it was in port in Spain, a Navy spokesman said. Lt. j.g. Robin E. Brown, 27, has been charged with one count of rape under the military code of justice and is awaiting judicial proceedings at the Naval Station in Rota, Spain, said Navy Lt. Scott Campbell, public affairs officer in Naples. Brown's hometown was not immediately known, Campbell said in a telephone interview late Friday. Brown is scheduled to go on trial for the alleged offense July 2 in Naples, Italy, Campbell said. The offense allegedly took place April 4 in the female officer's stateroom aboard the USS Suribachi. The Navy said it was withholding the woman's name and rank out of respect for her privacy. The woman is still on board the ammunition ship, while Brown has been assigned to other duties, the spokesman said. Maximum punishment for the offense is loss of all pay and military allowances from date of conviction, dismissal from the military and 30 years at hard labor, Campbell said. A pretrial investigation of the incident was conducted May 11 at the Naval Station in Rota, he said. The charge was referred to a general court martial proceeding, which was held May 26. Defense motions are expected to be made on June 15, with the trial to follow in July, Campbell said. The report of the alleged incident comes as the Navy has been struggling with the issue of the treatment of women within its ranks. The service has come under particular scrutiny after a female midshipman, Gwen Dreyer, resigned from the U.S. Naval Academy in Annapolis, Md., after she was handcuffed to a urinal and photographed by some male classmates. Her action prompted others, including men, to report hazing incidents at the military school. The incident also prompted the academy's superintendent, Rear Adm. Virgil Hill, to take a number of steps to tighten rules against harassement. Those found guilty of physical or mental abuse against plebes _ first year students _ now face expulsion. The academy also instituted a new program of sensitivity training for midshipmen that focuses on sexual harassment and equal opportunities.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker, Former Aides Examined to Determine If Fit For Jail
DOC.TEXT: Doctors are examining former hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker and other top members of his ousted regime to determine whether they are well enough to be jailed, an East German official said. Despite Health Minister Juergen Kleditzsch's announcement, it remains questionable whether the leaders of the former regime will go on trial. Kleditzsch's statement Friday marked the latest in a series of changing signals regarding the hated 77-year-old Honecker, who ruled East Germany in an authoritarian manner for 18 years until his downfall last October. Officials said late last year they would try Honecker for high treason, but later said they were dropping prosecution plans altogether because of the deposed leader's failing health. There has been similar uncertainty regarding the trials of some of Honecker's aging and ailing former top lieutenants. Most of the allegations against them center on corruption and abuse of office. In a parliamentary debate broadcast live on East German television, Kleditzsch indicated that some criminal proceedings are again being considered. ``At the request of the chief prosecutor, there is a team of expert doctors dealing with whether Honecker and other members of the Communist Party and national leadership can be jailed and interrogated,'' said Kleditzsch. The health minister added that Honecker and the others, whom he did not name, have been in a government hospital in East Berlin since May 28. Kleditzsch offered no further details. Earlier in the debate, one member of parliament, Bernhardt Opitz, said he wanted to know whether Honecker can be tried for ``crimes against humanity.'' The other top target of the criminal allegations is Erich Mielke, the 82-year-old former head of the once-dreaded secret police. At the moment the county is grappling with other major problems that might make many East Germans eager to avoid what would likely become a major show trial. Those problems include massive unemployment and possible unrest likely to grip the country late this summer and in the autumn, once the West German currency replaces the East German mark as part of the economic merger of the two Germanys. East German leaders also are working to resolve the stalemate over the question of the military status of a united Germany. The Soviet Union has opposed proposals that a unified Germany belong to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization. Last month, Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel said Honecker's failing health made a trial unlikely. Diestel, who is also the country's deputy prime minister, said he would not consider such a prosecution simply as a means of ``appeasing the people's anger.'' Honecker was arrested on Jan. 29, freed the following day and sent to live with a Lutheran pastor and his wife in the town of Lobetal. The former leader, who suffers from kidney cancer, was later taken to the Soviet military hospital in the town of Beelitz before his transfer to the government hospital in East Berlin.

DOC.HEAD: Multiparty System Faces Decisive Test In Algeria, Tunisia
DOC.TEXT: Voter readiness to accept multiparty democracy is being put to a decisive test in Algeria and Tunisia in local elections Sunday and Tuesday. In each of the North African neighbors, the governing party has held sole power since French colonial rule ended decades ago, and that party is virtually certain to win control of a large majority of councils. The main question is the level of support amassed by radical Islamic groups among voters unaccustomed to being given a choice. Fundamentalist groups have aligned under the banner of the Islamic Salvation Front in Algeria, where Tuesday's election will be the first under a multiparty system. The Front's candidates are running in almost all the 1,541 municipalities and provincial councils. But in Tunisia, the government has withheld official recognition of Islamic groups on the grounds that God belongs to all Tunisians. The fundamentalists have declared an official boycott of Sunday's elections, so anti-government sentiment will be gauged by the number of abstentions. The elections will be the second time Tunisian voters have had a free choice. In legislative elections in 1988, the governing Constitutional Democratic Rally won every seat in the National Assembly. Opposition parties later accused the party in power of having abused its control of state funds, transport and mass media. By contrast, a genuine election contest is expected in Algeria. Almost all parties will compete and have proclaimed in advance that they will accept the results. However, the Algerian situation is not simple. Many democratic parties, seeking an alternative to both the government and the fundamentalists, have entered candidates. But they are divided, in some cases more hostile to each other than to the governing National Liberation Front. One coalition, the Front of Socialist Forces, has called for an election boycott despite its potential for a strong showing. Another factor is the position taken by the followers of Ahmed Ben Bella, the former president ousted by a military coup in 1965 and now an exile in Switzerland. Both the National Liberation Front and the fundamentalists have urged backers of Ben Bella's Movement for Democracy in Algeria to join their side, but Ben Bella has given no endorsement. The future stance of the powerful Algerian army also remains in doubt. The fundamentalists are openly calling for military intervention to establish an ``Islamic republic,'' but senior army officers seem more likely to support a state free of religious interference. In both Tunisia and Algeria, the vote is for a list of locally selected party candidates. In each, an official result may not be announced for days. In one respect, the two voting systems differ markedly. Tunisia has a Western-style one-person, one-vote system resulting from a modern family code established by former President Habib Bourguiba. In Algeria, the family code is based on Islamic principles, and a man can vote on behalf of his wife _ or wives _ without having to produce any document authorizing him to do so.

DOC.HEAD: Ransom Raised; Waiting Begins for Hostage's Family
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS typo in `guerrillas' in grafs 1 and 5
DOC.TEXT: Roy and Marge Heimdal waited this weekend for word about their kidnapped son after they wired $60,000 from a frantic fund-raising campaign to the guerrillas believed to be holding him in Colombia. The Heimdals marched into a bank Friday clutching coffee cans stuffed with dollar bills about 90 minutes before a deadline to wire the money to a bank in Quito, Ecuador. They also sent a videotaped plea for mercy for their son, Scott Heimdal, 27, who was ambushed April 28 in northern Ecuador. ``I pleaded for my son's life,'' Mrs. Heimdal said. ``I begged. I said, `Please give me my son back. He's my only son.''' ``I've never begged before. I don't know if I did it right.'' An intermediary was to take the money into the jungle along the Ecuador-Colombia border this weekend in search of the kidnappers, whom U.S. officials have identified as Maoist guerrillas. The kidnappers originally sought $1.2 million but lowered their demand to $60,000. But the Heimdals lost their life savings paying medical bills after Mrs. Heimdal, 47, was severely injured in an accident with an uninsured drunken driver several years ago. On Tuesday they went on television to appeal for help raising the ransom. Nursing homes held bake sales, waitresses donated their tips and children handed over their piggy banks, and in four days the Heimdals had $60,000. ``A shiver went down my spine when they told me we had $60,000,'' Roy Heimdal said. ``I'm stunned.'' The Heimdals declined to disclose exactly how much money was raised, fearing the kidnappers might demand more. They have promised a full accounting after their son's release. Even as the Heimdals fought their way through a herd of reporters into the bank, strangers approached with dollar bills for their overflowing coffee cans and words of encouragement. ``I just want you to know we're all pulling for you,'' an unidentified young girl told Mrs. Heimdal before walking off. The family hopes the ordeal will be capped next week by a communitywide welcome home celebration for their son, who has worked the past two years for International Mining Co., which mines gold near Quito. He was traveling by boat with four others when the group was ambushed. The pilot was killed and another was injured. The kidnappers, reportedly members of a Colombian group known as the Popular Liberation Army, have threatened to ``show us where his body is,'' Mrs. Heimdal said. In Quito, Jeffrey Fino, manager of Iminco in Ecuador, reported no progress Friday in negotiations to free Scott Heimdal. A government source who demanded anonymity told The Associated Press that low-profile negotiations are most likely to succeed. The source said a Spanish bull salesman kidnapped last month in Quito was released unharmed upon payment of $1 million, and lack of publicity helped the negotiations.

DOC.HEAD: Nicaragua Devalues Currency in Advance of Summit
DOC.TEXT: The U.S.-backed government has devalued the national currency for the 11th time in six weeks in advance of a regional summit where Nicaragua will appeal for economic cooperation. The official ratio of Nicaraguan cordobas to U.S. dollars rose from 170,000:1 to 185,000:1 with Friday's action. Gas prices also increased by 1.4 cents a gallon. On the eve of the devaluation and price hikes, presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo said the economy will be the main subject of the Central American summit, scheduled for June 15 in Guatemala. ``Democracy will be established in the same measure that economically strong countries give Central America the chance of pulling ahead,'' he said in comments broadcast on national radio. ``Social and economic development benefits peace in the region.'' Lacayo said the administration of Violeta Barrios de Chamorro has contributed its share to bringing peace to the region. He pointed to both the plan to disband the Contra rebels and reduce the size of the army. The advent of Mrs. Chamorro's government to power six weeks ago brought hopes for an end to the country's nine-year-old civil war. The U.S.-backed Contras had battled the leftist Sandinista government, which was defeated in February elections. The dismantling of the Contra army, which was suspended several times, has picked up steam since rebel leaders and Mrs. Chamorro's administration signed an accord on May 30. It calls for the rebels to surrender their weapons by June 10. It also stipulates the creation of regional development centers for disarmed rebels, which they can police on their own. As of Thursday, 6,842 rebels had disarmed in seven security zones nationwide, said an official of the U.N. peacekeeping mission for Central America. However, Contra leaders have estimated the size of their force at 13,000. In addition, Mrs. Chamorro is studying a plan to trim the Sandinista People's Army. The president is expected to announce the final plan Sunday. Nicaragua hopes to promote peace and economic development with the help of $300 million in emergency aid approved by the U.S. Congress last month and $120 million promised during a conference of donor countries in Rome on Thursday. The donor countries also promised Nicaragua $180 million more for 1991. Participants in the summit will be Nicaragua, El Salvador, Costa Rica, Honduras and Guatemala.

DOC.HEAD: Store Owner Arrested on Obscenity Charge
LaserPhotos MH1,2
DOC.TEXT: Sheriff's deputies made their first arrest of a record retailer under a federal judge's ruling deeming a rap record by 2 Live Crew obscene. The band's leader said his record label will help pay legal fees. The group performed its sexually explicit material live in Miami Beach early today. Authorities did not interfere with the 45-minute show. The audience cheered when band leader Luther Campbell shouted vulgarities about Gov. Bob Martinez and Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro, whose deputies Friday arrested E-C Records owner Charles Freeman, 31, on misdemeanor charges of distributing obscene material. The deputies burst into the store after an undercover agent bought the group's recording ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' which U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez ruled Wednesday is obscene. The ruling did not affect live performances. If convicted, Freeman could be sentenced to a year in jail and fined $1,000. He was released from county jail on $100 bond. ``The inevitable has finally occurred,'' said Robyn E. Blumner, executive director of the American Civil Liberties Union in Florida. ``Someone in Broward is facing jail time because he sold a record album to an adult. ``That action put south Florida about on a par with Eastern Europe _ a year ago.'' Blumner said the ACLU will offer to represent Freeman. ``Someone has got to stand up and say this is wrong,'' she said. Freeman's case probably will go before a jury that will have to decide whether the album is criminally obscene. Gonzalez found in a civil case that the sexually explicit recording was without social value, appealed only to prurient interests and violated community standards in Dade, Broward and Palm Beach counties. Lyrics of many of the songs on the album contain misogynist and violent references, though they're tempered with humor. Navarro said his deputies went to Freeman's store after Freeman was quoted in news reports as saying he would sell the album despite the ban. ``We could not in good conscience allow him to flagrantly ignore the court's order,'' Navarro said at a news conference Friday. Campbell, owner and president of the group's record label, Luke's, said the company will help pay the legal fees of people arrested for selling the album. ``Somebody has to stand up and the retailers, I think, should stand up,'' Campbell said. ``We can give them some of the contacts we used in our case and we can help them financially.'' Campbell did not give specifics. The Miami-based rap group sued after Navarro, acting on the ruling of a county judge who said the material was ``probably obscene,'' sent his deputies in March to warn retailers they faced arrest. Gonzalez said the sheriff's office engaged in prior restraint of free speech by threatening owners before the recording was ruled obscene. The judge's obscenity ruling has no legal effect outside south Florida, but civil libertarians see a practical effect spreading nationally. Lisa Penna, who attended the show at the Miami Beach nightclub, said the controversy surrounding the group is a ``political vehicle for people trying to get re-elected.'' Of the group's raps, she said, ``All of this has to be taken in jest.''

DOC.HEAD: She Campaigns to Prosecute Parents Who Prevent Medical Care
DOC.TEXT: Rita Swan knows the pain of losing a child for deliberate denial of medical attention. Now she is determined that other parents be prosecuted for making the same decision. Work from her home in this tiny northwest Iowa town, Ms. Swan takes credit for prompting more than two dozen prosecutions against parents whose children died as they followed religious teachings for treating illness with prayer. Most of the parents are members of Christian Science Church. So, at one time, was Ms. Swan. ``The right of a child to live should be the highest priority of a civilized society,'' she said. ``The Christian Scientists say the death of a child is one of the great mysteries of the ages, but I say the death is not mysterious at all. It is the logical and inevitable result of withholding medical attention.'' Rita and Doug Swan, a math teacher at a nearby college, formed the group Children's Health Care is a Legal Duty, or CHILD, in 1983, six years after their son Matthew died of meningitis at 15 months. Ms. Swan, 46, said there are 300 CHILD members in 42 states and Canada who monitor cases. ``In the '80s, 29 sets of prosecutions were filed for religious-based medical neglect,'' she said. ``That's an amazing turnaround. In general in the '70s, these children just died and nobody cared.'' The results are mixed, with verdicts ranging from acquittal to conviction on a charge of murder. The general counsel for the National Counsel Against Health Fraud said Ms. Swan singlehandedly has raised the question of medical neglect with prosecutors across the country. ``She puts a bug in their ears,'' said Michael Botts, of Kansas City, Mo. ``She's the one who deserves the credit. It's her guts that did it. Without her, nothing would have been done.'' He said several courts have ruled that parents can be held accountable for the death of a child, notwithstanding religious beliefs. ``You've got parents playing Abraham out there. They believe if their religion is strong enough, the child will be saved. It's nothing short of human sacrifice to prove the strength of religious convictions,'' he said. Other courts have dismissed such actions, however, based on ``religious exemptions'' in state child abuse laws. Christian Scientists say healing-by-prayer is usually successful and protected by guarantees of religious freedom. ``We all grieved over her son, but she has now used it to wage a vendetta against the church,'' said Wendell Deware, a Christian Scientist practitioner from Davenport. A small number of children in the care of Christian Science practitioners do die, Deware said, but, ``we encounter such situations so rarely. ``The media has concentrated so much on these failures, they will not take into account the vast majority of successes.'' The church, founded in 1879 by Mary Baker Eddy, believes that physical disease, like sin, can be healed by spiritual means alone. There are about 2,600 Christian Science churches in 68 countries. Most states, including Iowa, prohibit the filing of child-abuse charges against parents who use prayer in treatment of their children, but prosecutors have filed other charges in several jurisdictions. The Swans, then living in a suburb of Detroit, sued the church after Matthew died in 1977. The U.S. Supreme Court, without comment, let stand a lower court ruling that barred the lawsuit on religious freedom grounds. ``He died of meningitis, the common and most treatable form,'' Ms. Swan said. ``He had three terrible fevers about a month apart preceding this illness. Each time, we called a Christian Scientist practitioner and he got well. Based on ignorance, we thought the practitioner had accomplished something significant.'' A fourth fever claimed the boy's life. Ms. Swan said she is ``driven by my sense of duty to our son'' to seek prosecutions in other cases. ``I'm proudest of the prosecutions. I think that's my strongest weapon against the church. It's not vindictiveness. It's something that has got to change. I feel our work has almost singlehandedly turned the country around on this issue to the point where the death of a Christian Science child will almost certainly get some scrutiny.''

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Strike East, Midwest
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms struck parts of the East and Midwest early today. Clouds shrouded much of the nation. Thunderstorms hit New York, Missouri and Pennsylvania. Hail, heavy rain and damaging winds were expected in New York and Vermont, but the Appalachian region faced the greatest risk of thunderstorms. On Friday, thunderstorms produced high winds, flooding, large hail and tornadoes in parts of the Plains, the Midwest and along the southern Atlantic coast. A tornado and hail up to 2{ inches in diameter struck near Emporia, Kan., a day after 21 people were injured by a twister there. There were no reports of major damage from the latest tornado. Tornadoes and thunderstorms produced flooding in Ohio, but there were no reports Friday of serious damage. Hail the size of baseballs pelted Evansville, Ind. Thunderstorm winds blew down trees and power lines near York and Gettysburg in Pennsylvania and in the Virginia cities of Virginia Beach and Portsmouth. Lightning set many fires across central North Carolina and in Adams County, Pa., the National Weather Service said. Temperatures were in the 80s and 90s across much of the nation Friday. Greer, S.C., set a record high temperature for the date with a reading of 96 degrees. The high Friday in the Lower 48 states was 111 degrees at Lake Havasu City, Ariz. DOC.HEAD: Death Toll Climbs in Central Asia Violence
DOC.TEXT: The death toll in a week of ethnic fighting between Uzbeks and Kirghiz in Central Asia has climbed to 102, the Tass news agency said today. Thousands of troops have been sent to the region by the Soviet Defense Ministry, but the situation in the neighboring republics of Uzbekistan and Kirghizia remained volatile today, Tass said in a dispatch from the Kirghizian capital of Frunze. Quoting the republic's Interior Ministry, it said 102 people have been killed and 436 have been wounded since Monday. A total of 225 homes, 31 state buildings and 62 cars have been torched since the violence broke out, Tass said. It said the damage occurred both in Frunze and in Osh, on the border with Uzbekistan. Tass said 68 of those killed were in the Uzgen district, 36 miles from Osh. Clashes between ethnic Kirghiz and Uzbeks _ both Sunni Moslems _ began June 2, and the fighting intensified Monday, Soviet officials said. In dispute is the allocation of plots of land for housing in the densely populated, poverty-stricken region. On Friday, the president of Uzbekistan declared a state of emergency in border districts in the republic because of what Tass called ``a sharp aggravation of the situation.'' A state of emergency also was in effect in the Kirghiz border city of Osh, where troops patrolled the streets, and in Frunze. Uzbek President Islam Karimov, who declared the state of emergency on his side of the border, sent an urgent telegram to President Mikhail S.
