DOC.TEXT: Actor Jim Varney, in the person of Ernest P. Worrell _ that ``Hey Vern'' rube of movie and advertising fame _ has been drafted to pitch the Atlanta Braves. No, he isn't on the mound, but the cellar-dwelling Braves probably couldn't do much worse if he were. The Braves' front office has been taking some heat for trotting out Ernest as a promotion gimmick with all the subtlety befitting the character. On radio, fans hear Ernest yelling at Vern to buy tickets _ as often as every half-inning. At the ballpark, Ernest's 6-foot-tall face grins maniacally above the Gate G ticket windows. Braves' promotions director Miles McRea can't understand why everybody's down on Ernest, a veteran pitchman of numerous television commercials. ``His movies are hits,'' McRea said. ``He's been used for Coca-Cola, Disney _ reputable companies. But who gets all the (media) play for using him? We do.''

DOC.HEAD: Man Suffers Broken Leg But Rescued From Disposal Truck
DOC.TEXT: A man catching a nap in a garbage bin was scooped up by a disposal truck that began crushing the load, breaking the sleeper's leg before a passerby heard screams and alerted the driver. ``I heard him yell `Help!' and I thought it was a guy singing into a radio,'' said passerby Bobby J. Sanders, an Alaska fisherman. ``I never thought there would be anybody inside a garbage truck.'' Taylor Glenn Doughty, a transient, recalled being squashed twice before the machinery stopped, police said after questioning him at a hospital. The truck operator believes he inadvertently picked up Doughty at a paper company about three blocks from where the rescue was made late Thursday, police said. Doughty said he couldn't be sure where he was picked up, because ``I was pretty snockered.''

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards $5.27 Million to Woman Paralyzed in Toyota Truck Accident
DOC.TEXT: A faulty Toyota pickup design was cited as a jury awarded $5.27 million to a woman for injuries they suffered in a 1984 accident. The Superior Court jury also awarded $100,000 to the two daughters of Cynthia Gosper, 35, of Garden Grove, who was left a quadriplegic from the accident during a family vacation in Arizona. The daughters suffered minor injuries in the same accident. Attorneys for Toyota Motor Sales U.S.A. Inc. of Torrance said they will appeal Friday's decision. Jurors found that a design flaw in the 1981 4-wheel-drive SR5 pickup Gosper was driving allowed it to roll off a highway after it was struck from behind. The driver's side door popped open, throwing Gosper from the truck. Officials with Toyota Motor Sales said the award was one of the largest ever imposed against the company. Toyota attorneys insisted at trial that the truck's design is safe and that the force of the collision caused it to roll over. An analyst with the Center for Auto Safety, a Washington-based group founded by consumer advocate Ralph Nader, praised the decision. ``I think the jury was correct in their decision that the vehicle was designed in an unstable manner,'' said analyst Sam Cole. The $100,000 will be split between Gosper's two daughters, Christine, 11, and Melissa, 9, who suffered cuts and bruises in the accident.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Leaders Say Euthanasia Issue Involves Morals, Not Law
DOC.TEXT: Legal debates over a doctor helping an Alzheimer's sufferer commit suicide with his machine are missing the point, say religious leaders who believe such moral issues fall outside the realm of courts. ``Suicide is a word for self-murder, and some 5,000 years of Judeo-Christian morality has always defined it as wrong,'' said Jay Berman, spokesman for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit. ``And to aid in that would be equally morally wrong. ``The debate over euthanasia is cast today solely in terms of legal and illegal,'' he said. ``The debate should actually address what is morally right and morally wrong.'' The debate was renewed by the death of Janet Adkins, 54, of Portland, Ore. On Monday, she rode with Dr. Jack Kevorkian and two of his sisters in his rusty Volkswagen van to a park north of Detroit. There, she pushed the button on a device that pumped lethal chemicals into her veins. Death came within five or six minutes, Kevorkian said. Adkins told Kevorkian she had been diagnosed with incurable Alzheimer's disease and sought help from the retired pathologist in committing suicide. Oakland County Circuit Judge Alice Gilbert ordered Kevorkian on Friday to not use his device until prosecutors determine whether it is legal. Michigan courts have differed in interpreting Michigan law in such cases. But laws aren't the question, Berman said Friday. Deeming something legal doesn't make it automatically right, he argued. ``It's legal to drive a car up to a 0.10 blood-alcohol level, but it's not right.'' Adkins and her husband, Ronald, discussed her death wish with their minister, Alan G. Deale of the First Unitarian Church in Portland, where a memorial service for Adkins was scheduled for Sunday afternoon. Deale said his denomination supports the right to self-determination for those who become terminally ill. Adkins was in the early stages of Alzheimer's, a degenerative brain and nerve disorder that robs people of their memories, ability to function and eventually their lives. An estimated 4 million U.S. adults, mostly over age 65, have the disease. Her husband said she despaired as her memory failed. ``We support the whole idea that the dignity of life must be maintained,'' Deale said. ``But we support the freedom of choice. Life only has dignity if it has some quality.'' Muhammed Karoub of the Detroit-based Federation of Islamic Associations disagreed. Kevorkian and Adkins, he said, ``interfered in a normal process that might better be left to God and the medical profession.'' ``In the Islamic religion, God works through his learned people, including doctors. Sometimes (doctors) have to temper their feelings. They have to be careful; almost an arrogance creeps in when dealing with life and death,'' Karoub said. The Eastern Orthodox Church considers euthanasia unacceptable under any circumstances, said the Rev. Demetrios Kavadas, pastor of Assumption Greek Orthodox Church in suburban St. Clair Shores. ``No one, apart from God who gives life and death, has the right to take the life of another,'' he said. Sister Elizabeth McMillan of the St. Louis-based Catholic Health Association said she considered Kevorkian's actions immoral and unethical. ``What concerns me about the involvement of a physician in the taking of a life is that it undermines in a radical and important way the trust that has to be there between patient and physician and community and physician,'' McMillan said. ``Doctors are supposed to be healers.'' President William F. Schultz of the Boston-based Unitarian Universalist Association said such criticism is hypocritical and absurd. ``Doctor-assisted suicide is humane. It's far more humane than allowing individuals to botch the job in a suicide attempt, which creates far more suffering for the self and loved ones. So I'm supportive of doctor-assisted suicide,'' he said. Kevorkian is scornful of religion and its influence over the medical profession, which largely has condemned his views on euthanasia. ``Religious dogma has become part of the marrow of humanity. We can't get rid of it,'' he said during a March interview. ``There should be absolutely no connection between medicine and religion, but there is, and it's paralyzing.'' Berman said Kevorkian and other advocates have wrongly presented euthanasia as compassionate. ``I personally have, in Vietnam, heard wounded soldiers cry out, `Kill me, kill me.' All our moral intonation is to help them recover and, failing that, to alleviate their suffering. But we can never kill them.''

DOC.HEAD: Thatcher Hailed by Oppositon Lawmakers for Helping Free Them
DOC.TEXT: Newly elected opposition lawmakers on Saturday praised British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher for her anti-Communist ideology at an impromptu meeting of Ukraine's Communist-dominated Parliament. The Conservative Party prime minister, standing beneath a giant statue of Lenin, engaged in lively exchanges about democracy with deputies assembled at the Supreme Soviet of the Ukraine. But, seated beside the Parliament's Communist president, Volodymyr Ivashko, Mrs. Thatcher backed down when opposition members urged her to recognize Soviet Lithuania and to declare support for separatists in the Ukraine. ``I can see you are trying to get me involved in your politics,'' she said. Mrs. Thatcher addressed the Ukraine's Parliament on the third day of her four-day visit to the Soviet Union. She arrived here after conferring with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow on Friday. The visit is aimed partly at showing solidarity with Gorbachev, beset by acute economic problems and secessionist moves as he battles to implement his reform policies. Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia have taken steps toward seceding from the Soviet Union, while separatists in some of the other Soviet republics have indicated they would like to follow suit. Several hundred separatists demonstrated outside the Kiev Parliament holding placards denouncing ``imperialist Moscow.'' The lawmakers, two-thirds of whom belong to the Communist Party _ which won handsomely in the Republic's first free elections this year _ gave Mrs. Thatcher a standing ovation after her address. Questions began with a bland inquiry about policy making in Britain, but quickly became controversial when members of four non-Communist parties that have formed an opposition grouping took the floor. Opposition member Genrikh Altunyan said he was one of 10 former political prisoners in the new Parliament. ``We know it is due to you and to President Reagan that we have been able to be here today,'' said Altunyan. ``We are very thankful to you and will never forget your support when we languished in labor camps.'' There was scattered applause, but most lawmakers stared ahead in silence. Altunyan, an Armenian, spent 9{ years in prison or labor camps from 1969 to 1987 for ``anti-Soviet activities.'' Mrs. Thatcher thanked him, but said: ``It is necessary for democracy to be underpinned by the rule of law ... rights clearly stated, infringements also clearly stated.'' Another opposition member, Igor Juchnovksy, told Mrs. Thatcher he was disappointed that Britain did not recognize Lithuania as a sovereign state. He also said that Britain should open an embassy in the Ukraine. Mrs. Thatcher replied saying that Britain did not, for example, have an embassy in California or in the Canadian province of Quebec. In her address, Mrs. Thatcher stressed a central theme of her visit: admiration for the Soviet Union in its daunting task of reform. ``You are bringing about in the Soviet Union changes of a magnitude which have never been attempted before in history,'' she said. ``We wish you well.'' In Moscow earlier, Mrs. Thatcher assured six Jewish refuseniks _ citizens who have been refused permission to emigrate _ that Britain will continue campaigning for emigration rights. But she reaffirmed her opposition to Israel settling emigrants in the occupied territories. On Friday, during a news conference with Gorbachev, Mrs. Thatcher said Israel was ``almost letting down those of us who have campaigned vigorously'' for Jewish emigration. Gorbachev reiterated warnings that he may curb Jewish emigration, at a record high under his liberalized policies, unless Israel stops emigrants from settling in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Israel says that about 35,000 Soviet Jews have arrived this year. But it says it has no policy of settling them in territories seized in the 1967 Middle East war, and that only a few hundred have settled there so far. Several thousand people pressed against police barriers and cheered as Mrs. Thatcher arrived in Kiev Saturday to tour a British trade and cultural exhibition. She was greeted by a British military band playing ``Scotland the Brave.'' She later took a brief walk through the center of Kiev and visited the city's towering Babi Yar monument. It stands at a gully in a park where 100,000 Jews and other Ukrainians were slaughtered during the Nazi occupation in World War II. On Sunday, Mrs. Thatcher travels to a region of Armenia that was devastated by an earthquake 18 months ago.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Won't Let Dogs Visit Jailed Animal Rights Activist
DOC.TEXT: A jailed animal rights activist may not have a visit from her dogs while she awaits sentencing on an attempted murder conviction, a judge ruled. U.S. District Judge Peter C. Dorsey ruled Friday that state correction officials are not obligated to allow Fran Stephanie Trutt's four dogs to visit her at the Niantic prison for women. Trutt's lawyer, John Williams, said he will press on with efforts to allow visits with her dogs after Trutt is sentenced. ``It's easy to make a joke about this,'' Williams said. ``But the truth of the matter is her dogs are her only friends.'' Under a plea agreement, Trutt is expected to be sentenced in July to a term that would end March 31, 1991. ``An exception in the plaintiff's situation will provide a basis for similar requests by others and for all sorts of animals,'' Dorsey said. Trutt, 34, pleaded no contest in April to a charge that she planted a bomb in the parking lot of U.S. Surgical Corp., in an attempt to kill the company's chairman, Leon Hirsch. The company uses laboratory dogs in showing surgeons how to use its patented surgical staplers, which can be used in place of sutures.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Soviet Soldiers Fire On West German Plane
DOC.TEXT: Soviet soldiers opened fire on a West German private plane after it crossed into Soviet airspace on Saturday, the semiofficial Anatolia news agency reported. The plane apparently was not hit. The dispatch said the plane, apparently a transport aircraft, took off from the Black Sea coastal province of Trabzon about noon for the Iranian city of Tabriz. When the plane reached the Turkish-Soviet border at Sarp, Soviet soldiers opened fire on it, Anatolia said. Cafer Yildiz, acting governor of Artvin province at the Soviet border, told The Associated Press by telephone that Turkish military authorities at the border witnessed the incident. He said they saw the plane return to Turkish airspace and continue flying east. The whereabouts of the plane were unknown after the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Observers; Gov't Bans Exit Polls And Unofficial Results
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 12 grafs to UPDATE with government banning exit polls and unofficial results. Pickup 11th graf pvs, `Half the...' Minor editing to trim.
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of local and foreign observers will look on when Bulgarians cast ballots Sunday in the country's first free elections in 58 years. The parliamentary vote pits the leadership of the old Communist Party, now renamed the Socialist Party, against an opposition coalition called the Union of Democratic Forces, which wants a swift move to a Western-style market economy. The government on Saturday night announced a ban on all exit polls and the circulation of any information about the election results before the official announcement by the Central Electoral Commission, the state news agency BTA reported. The commission, acting on a protest from the main opposition alliance, on Thursday banned an exit poll to be conducted by the West German Infas institute with Bulgarian partners. The race includes the Socialists and 36 other parties vying for the 400 seats in the Grand National Assembly. Only one other party, the Bulgarian Agrarian Party, is expected to win a significant number of votes. Almost 6.5 million of the nearly 9 million Bulgarians are eligible to vote in the first multiparty elections since 1932. Official pre-election surveys have given the ruling Socialists _ heirs to four decades of totalitarian rule _ a commanding lead of between 42 percent and 49 percent of the vote. The same polls have shown the Union of Democratic Forces a distant second with 21 percent to 28 percent of the vote and the mainstream Agrarian Party third with 10 percent to 15 percent. In a recent interview Union chairman Zhelyu Zhelev rejected the official forecasts as ``manipulations'' and said his coalition hoped for at least 50 percent of the vote. Diplomats and some Bulgarian observers predicted a fairly close race between the Socialists and the Union. The polls open at 7 a.m. and close at 6 p.m., with a possible one-hour extension if people are still waiting in lines at 6 p.m. Vote counting was to begin shortly after the polls closed, but it was not clear when initial results would be released. Half the seats in Parliament will be decided by direct vote and half by proportional representation. Parties must get a minimum of 4 percent of the vote to win any seats in Parliament. A runoff election is scheduled on June 17 for races in which no candidate gets more than 50 percent of the vote. The campaign was marred by some violence and a lot of mudslinging, largely between the government's newspaper, Duma, and the opposition daily, Demokratsiya. Several deaths during the campaign are under investigation, among them the slaying of a sympathizer of the Union of Democratic Forces, shot and killed by an army officer in northern Shumen. However, leaders of the three leading parties refrained from personal attacks in a televised debate broadcast live Friday night, apparently hoping to avoid antagonizing voters. Zhelev, Socialist chief Alexander Lilov and Agrarian leader Viktor Valkov agreed on the need for a coalition government to tackle the nation's serious economic and political problems. But Zhelev insisted his alliance would not govern alongside the former Communists. Many international organizations as well as individual countries have sent observers to watch the balloting. On Friday, an American-led international observer group criticized flaws in the electoral process. The group cited the exclusion of about 200,000 ethnic Turks who fled Bulgaria last summer to escape religious and ethnic persecution under former Communist leader Todor Zhivkov, who was ousted in November. The leader of a citizens' group, the Association for Free and Fair Elections, said about 10,000 members would monitor voting. ``We have never had free and fair elections,'' said Kevork Kevorkyan, the group's leader. ``This is the main reason why we undertake such an effort.'' ``One does not get easily accustomed to freedom.''

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Plans To Leave Warsaw Pact, Prime Minister Says
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Jozsef Antall said Saturday that Hungary intends to fully withdraw from the Warsaw Pact even if the alliance plans to dissolve eventually. But he said Hungary wanted to negotiate its pullout with the other six member nations rather than making a move on its own. Antall spoke to reporters Saturday after returning from a Warsaw Pact meeting in Moscow, where he said he had conveyed the Hungarian position to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ``We made it clear that given the altered circumstances, we consider the Warsaw Pact and in particular its military aspect outdated,'' he said. ``We also made it clear that we want to leave the military organization of the Pact and the Warsaw Pact itself, even if it is not dissolved.'' Asked about Moscow's response, Antall said: ``The Soviet leaders acknowledged our position.'' At the summit, the allies began planning the transformation from a military to a political body in the wake of the momentous changes in Europe. ``The Warsaw Pact in its present form plays a certain diplomatic and political role,'' Antall said. But he said Hungarian leaders believe ``the military aspect of the Pact should be dissolved by the end of 1991.'' Moscow has agreed to remove all its troops stationed on Hungarian territory by the middle of next year. The Hungarian leader said Hungary wants to regain control of its own military as well. ``We told Moscow that we intend to restore full sovereignty over the Hungarian armed forces, revamp our forces into a defensive organization, and will not participate in joint Warsaw Pact military exercises,'' Antall said. Antall said Hungary would ``take her armed forces from under Warsaw Pact command even while we are still a member.'' In an interview published Saturday in the West Berlin newspaper Morgenpost, East Germany's defense minister, Rainer Eppelmann, predicted the breakup of the Warsaw Pact's military structures this year. Polish Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowieczki, who is currently visiting Budapest and joined Antall at the news conference, declined to comment directly on the Hungarian position. However, he said work on establishing a collective European security system as favored by the Warsaw Pact members ``must begin without delay.'' Antall said Hungary was mindful of regional effects of its actions. ``We do not want to make a move that would disturb the German reunification process, nor one that could possibly upset the timetable of the Soviet troop withdrawals from Hungary,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Teen-Ager Hijacks Plane After Fight With Parents
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet runaway said Saturday he hijacked an Aeroflot airliner to Sweden because he was upset about a quarrel with his father over a broken moped. No one was hurt. The plane, carrying a crew of seven and 114 passengers, was on a domestic flight from the Byelorussian capital of Minsk to the Soviet Arctic port of Murmansk when the youth threatened the crew with a fake grenade, authorities said. The incident ended peacefully when Dimitry Semionov, 17, surrendered to police an hour after the Tupolev 154 jetliner landed at Stockholm's international airport. ``He just said he wanted to stay in Sweden,'' said police inspector Barry Ivarsson. None of the passengers knew the plane had been hijacked until it landed early Saturday at Arlanda airport, 25 miles north of Stockholm, one said. ``Everything was peaceful and quiet,'' passenger Marya Yeryomenko told a television interviewer before the flight returned to the Soviet Union. ``The stewardess only told us after we had landed that we were in Stockholm.'' Semionov, a high school student from Minsk, said his father had told him to get out of the house after their quarrel. ``My parents drove me away, my father did. I didn't have anywhere to stay,'' he said in a radio interview, speaking through an interpreter. ``I didn't wish to harm anyone, but I saw no other method. ... Everything got worse and worse and I was very disappointed.'' The plane was searched for explosives before it returned to the Soviet Union Saturday morning with its passengers. Semionov's lawyer, Birger Ohlson, said his client was in Stockholm's Kronoberg prison and would be arraigned Sunday. ``He had quarreled with his father about something as trivial as a broken moped,'' Ohlson said in a television interview. ``His father reprimanded him for not having mended it properly, so the boy got angry and sold the moped. His father wanted the money, and when he didn't get it he took the keys and drove him out.'' The lawyer said Semionov told him he had not planned the hijack, but ``got the idea on the plane.'' Semionov faced up to four years in a prison in Sweden but would be subject to much harsher punishment in the Soviet Union, the lawyer said. ``According to what has been said, he could face very grave consequences, even the death penalty,'' Ohlson said. Ohlson said Soviet authorities had not requested the youth's extradition. Semionov was expected to seek asylum. ``It may sound unpatriotic, but I know that the society here is freer and the change in our country is too slow,'' the teen-ager said in the radio interview. After the plane was commandeered, Finnish authorities initially refused it permission to fly through their airspace, but then relented. Alexander Krasilnikov, a spokesman for the Soviet ministry of civil aviation in Moscow, confirmed that the plane had returned safely and there were no injuries among the passengers and crew.

DOC.HEAD: Official: Defendant Made Escape Attempt
DOC.TEXT: One of two brothers charged with killing their wealthy parents apparently tried to escape, officials said after finding his leg chain was nearly severed. A Los Angeles County sheriff's deputy noticed the link on Lyle Menendez's leg chain was nearly cut through while he was unlocking the defendants' manacles for Friday's court appearance, said sheriff's Sgt. Robert Stoneman. ``It was cut to the point where just slight pressure or twisting would have broken the link,'' Stoneman said. ``We subsequently found in a search of their jail cells, handwritten documents that we seized that may be of evidentiary value concerning this escape attempt,'' Stoneman added. He refused to elaborate. No charges were immediately filed. The brothers, 22-year-old Lyle and 19-year-old Erik Menendez, are accused of murdering their parents. Jose Menendez, 45, and his wife, Kitty, 44, died Aug. 20 in the family's Beverly Hills mansion. The couple was hit numerous times with shotgun blasts. Menendez was a wealthy executive of Live Entertainment Inc., a video distribution company. The brothers claim they found the bodies when they returned home from a night out. Prosecutors allege the siblings were motivated to kill their parents to claim their father's wealth. Also Friday, the news media lost an attempt to be privy to conversations considered key evidence in the murder case of two brothers charged with killing their wealthy parents. Superior Court Judge James Albracht convened a separate hearing at which lawyers for The Associated Press, the Los Angeles Times and ABC-TV argued that matters being discussed in secret could be reviewed at least in part with the press and public present. But Albracht said he believed the issue being discussed _ a psychotherapist's privilege with his patients _ could not be adequately divulged without disclosing the material claimed to be privileged. The secret hearing dealt with tape recordings made by psychiatrist Jerome Oziel, who treated Erik and Lyle Menendez. Gerald Chaleff, attorney for Lyle Menendez, had asked that the hearing be held in secret on grounds that it could not be held in public without violating the psychotherapist's privilege.

DOC.HEAD: One Tourist Dead, One Missing In Sinking of Chartered Yacht
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with more precise location of accident, identities, other details; no pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An Austrian tourist died and her husband was missing after a chartered yacht collided Saturday with a freighter and sank in the Aegean Sea, an official said. It was unclear what caused the accident off Cape Sounion, 45 miles southeast of Athens, said a spokesman for the Merchant Marine Ministry. The dead woman was identified as Susanne Sagl, 57, and her husband as Hubert Sagl, 59, the ministry spokesman said on condition of anonymity. No information was available about the couple's hometown, he said. ``We have launched a full-scale search operation by air and sea but there are no signs of the man so far,'' the spokesman said. A passing cruise ship ferried the injured to Lavrion, a port near the site of the collision, and the remaining passengers and crew arrived later aboard the Anastassia K., an official at a Lavrion hospital said. The cause of Mrs. Sagl's death was not immediately clear, the official said on condition of anonymity. He said it appeared the yacht's mast might have struck her as the boat keeled over. The couple was traveling aboard the Greek Aghena yacht, which was carrying a crew of four and 20 West German and three Austrian tourists. Two other passengers were slightly injured when the yacht collided with the Anastassia K. freighter, the spokesman said. It was not clear how many crew members were aboard the freighter, but all were reported safe, he said. The Aghena had left Piraeus, near Athens, and was heading for the central Aegean island of Seriphos, part of the Kyklades island chain. The Anastassia K. was heading for Piraeus from the southeastern Aegean island of Rhodes, charting a course contrary to that of the yacht, the ministry spokesman said.

DOC.HEAD: South Africa Frees Political Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: President F.W. de Klerk freed 48 political prisoners Saturday in his latest effort aimed at improving the climate for black-white political negotiations. In an announcement Thursday, De Klerk had promised the releases and lifted the 4-year-old national state of emergency in three of four provinces. The African National Congress, the country's leading opposition group, welcomed the move, but said more than 3,000 activists remain imprisoned for politically motivated acts. ``We are happy to be released,'' said Jeffrey Radebe. ``But our happiness is not complete today when we think of all the comrades we left behind.'' Radebe, like most of the activists released Saturday, belongs to the ANC. Several were convicted in some of the country's most highly publicized terrorism and treason trials in recent years. Maj. Dave Smith, a spokesmen for the Prisons Service, said 28 inmates were released from the Robben Island Prison off Cape Town and 20 more were freed from other prisons. One of the men released, Stephen Nkosi, said he thought the 48 were freed as a publicity move to ``undercut'' the current international tour by African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela. Mandela is on a six-week tour of Europe, North America and Africa to urge foreign governments to maintain economic sanctions against South Africa to protest apartheid. Speaking in Geneva Saturday, Mandela said non-whites in South Africa face the same discrimination as when he was imprisoned 27 years ago. He urged the international community to continue its pressure against apartheid. ``The fact that he (de Klerk) has declared he wants a non-racial constitution does not mean apartheid has come to an end,'' said Mandela, who was freed from prison in February. In Brussels, the European Community welcomed the lifting of emergency rules, but did it not mention whether the 12-member trading bloc would lift its sanctions against Pretoria. The EC in 1986 banned imports of iron, steel and gold coins from South Africa and prohibited new EC investments in that country. Britain unilaterally lifted the investment ban after Mandela's release. Nkosi had been sentenced to 16 years in 1977 for what he described as ``ANC-related activities.'' He was among 28 men freed from Robben Island, where many prisoners went on a hunger strike earlier this year demanding their release. Ashraf Karriem, convicted in 1988 along with several others at a terrorism trial, hugged his ailing father at a tearful reunion in Cape Town. ``I've been praying for this day, I can die now,'' said the father Abdulrahman Karriem, 63. The ANC, the country's most powerful opposition group, has set lifting the state of emergency, releasing political prisoners and allowing the return of exiles were preconditions for black-white negotiations on ending apartheid. De Klerk says he wants to work out a new constitution with the opposition that will allow the country's 5 million whites to share power with the 28 million blacks, who currently have no voice in national affairs. Mid-level officials from the ANC and the government worked together last month to put together a report on several issues dividing the two sides, including the definition of a ``political prisoner.'' Also on Thursday, De Klerk said he would work toward allowing thousands of exiles to return. Mandela says 20,000 people currently live in exile. In Geneva, the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees, Thorvald Stoltenberg, said Saturday his agency would be ready to help repatriate political exiles once the ANC and the South African government reach agreement on their return. Meanwhile, a U.N. envoy heading a fact-finding mission to South Africa to determine the progress of reforms rejected a charge Saturday that he was interfering in the country's affairs. ``The question of apartheid is an international issue, the question of negotiations is very much a national issue,'' U.N. Under-Secretary Abdul Rahim Fahran said Saturday. His six-member team will spend 11 days in South Africa. Foreign Minister Pik Botha warned the United Nations this week not to interfere in South Africa's affairs. The warning reportedly came in a letter to U.N. secretary-general, Javier Perez de Cuellar.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Uprising 2{ Years Old; Shamir Seeks Improved Contacts With U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Palestinian in the occupied territories marked 2{ years of revolt against Israel Saturday with a general strike, and Arab reports said two Palestinians suspected of collaborating with Israel were slain. The new hard-line Cabinet of Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir faces confirmation in Parliament on Monday, but Israel radio reported that women in Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc threatened to disrupt a Likud meeting to approve the Cabinet lineup Sunday. In an interview broadcast on Israel radio Saturday, Shamir said he will seek contacts with the United States ``with more vigor.'' Relations with Washington have worsened recently while Shamir's interim government continued to reject a U.S. peace initiative and settle Soviet Jews in the occupied territories. Palestinians throughout the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip observed a general strike called by the pro-PLO underground leaders to mark ``the monthly anniversary for the uprising,'' a leaflet distributed in the territories said. Across the occupied lands, merchants closed their shops, public transportation was halted and children stayed home from school. In the Gaza Strip town of Rafah, Arab reporters said three masked men stabbed Jemal Abu Aziz, 29, with daggers and shot him to death near the el Faruk mosque. Residents said Aziz was known to work with Israeli security forces and that his body was taken away by the authorities, Arab reporters said. The army said it was a criminal matter and under police investigaton. In Jerusalem, police said they found the body of another Palestinian man stabbed overnight. Arab reporters identified the victim as Hamad Hamdan and said he had been accused of organizing the sale of Arab lands to Jewish settlers. Their deaths brought to 221 the number of Palestinians slain by fellow Arabs since the uprising began in December 1987. Most were killed on suspicion of collaborating with Israel or drug dealing or prostitution. A total of 716 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli troops and civilians, and 45 Israelis have died in the violence. Shamir faced a new threat when women members of the governing Likud Central Committee said they would distrupt Sunday's meeting, scheduled to confirm Shamir's new Cabinet, Israel radio said. It said 400 women planned to protest unless at least one female minister was appointed to the Cabinet. Ultra-Orthodox religious parties have opposed serving on a Cabinet with women. Shamir said on Israel radio that he hoped his new government would ``work with a united spirit without too many differences among its members.'' He said it was too early to consider a trip to Washington since his government had not been approved by the Knesset, or parliament. But, he said, he would pursue greater contact with the Americans. Israel television said contacts with the U.S. administration had ``practically been cut off'' since the national unity government, which included the center-left Labor Party led by Shimon Peres, fell apart on March 15. Shamir lost a vote of confidence then when Likud rejected left-of-center Labor's demand to accept a proposal by Secretary of State James A. Baker III for preliminary peace talks with Palestinians. According to its guidelines, Shamir's new government promises to maintain its May 1989 peace initiative promising Palestinian elections. At the same time, the new government has pledged to expand settlements in the occupied lands and use harsh measures against the Palestinian revolt. With his delicate, two-seat majority in the 120-member Parliament, Shamir also faces the possiblilty of collapse should his right-wing partners reject his peace moves. Some of the partners oppose autonomy for the Palestinians in the occupied territories.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Lives in Fear of Fugitive Ex-Husband
DOC.TEXT: A woman who is living in hiding while police search for clues to the whereabouts of her fugitive ex-husband says the system has failed her and other battered women. Janet Pearson fears for her life. Authorities say they can't afford to give her around-the-clock protection from Marvin Pearson, her former spouse, who is accused of kidnapping and terrorizing his ex-wife and 13-year-old daughter with a sawed-off shotgun last Christmas Eve, less than two weeks after being released from prison after a previous threat. Pearson, 47, escaped May 25 from the Benton County Jail. He and another inmate cut through a wire covering the jail's exercise area. The other inmate surrendered the next morning, but Pearson has not been spotted since his escape. ``If he can find me, I know he will kill me,'' Ms. Pearson, 41, said Friday before leaving the Fayetteville Battered Women's Shelter for another, perhaps safer, place to live. ``I have no protection, no freedom, and none of it is my fault,'' she said. ``The laws are such that a battered woman has no place to turn. I'm in danger and everyone I associate with is in danger.'' The leave she took from her job at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Fayetteville expires in a week. She has worked at the hospital for 10 years but said she has no guarantee that the job still will be open if and when police recapture her former husband and she can come out of hiding. Ms. Pearson requested 24-hour police protection, but Benton County Sheriff Andrew Lee said he could not oblige because of a shortage of money and manpower. Pearson gained early release from the state Department of Correction on Dec. 15 under the state's Emergency Powers Act, which authorizes prison officials to hasten the parole of some eligible prisoners to ease overcrowding. He had been sentenced to prison for a previous threat against Ms. Pearson and was denied parole on July 1989. Neither his ex-wife nor Benton County authorities knew Pearson was out of prison until he appeared Christmas Eve at Ms. Pearson's mobile home near Lowell in rural Benton County and threatened to kill her. After about 30 minutes, Pearson's daughter managed to call for help. Pearson fled in a pickup, which he forced his wife to drive at gunpoint. After a short chase, he abandoned the vehicle and managed to elude officers who conducted a manhunt with dogs and helicopters. Ms. Pearson was not injured. Gov. Bill Clinton criticized prison officials' decision on Pearson's early release. Pearson later made threatening telephone calls to his ex-wife at her job, where the telephones had been tapped. Authorities traced the calls to Phoenix, Ariz., where FBI agents arrested Pearson on Jan. 6. ``My life has been a living hell for the last three years. It hasn't changed now, so what's going to hurt?'' Ms. Pearson said, explaining why she agreed to talk to the news media about her situation. ``Things can change for the better only when people speak up when their rights are being violated and their needs aren't being addressed,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Yeltsin Appeals for Calm, Promises Improvements
DOC.TEXT: Russian Federation President Boris N. Yeltsin on Saturday promised to improve the economy in the Soviet Union's largest republic within three years but warned the situation was so tense that ``any spark ... could create a fire.'' The unsual 20-minute interview with the newly elected head of the Russian republic was broadcast on state TV the same day it was announced that several Yeltsin allies lost first-round elections to Russia's new legislature. The silver-haired Yeltsin, 59, put aside his criticism of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and instead appealed for consolidation. Referring to the sagging economy, Yeltsin said, ``We will find a way out of the situation.'' But his offered few details of his plan. He appealed specifically to coal miners, who this summer will mark the first anniversary of a strike that damaged the economy and depleted the nation's coal supplies. Some miners want to renew the walkout, and a decision could come at a miners' conference this week in the Ukraine. ``I would like somehow to calm miners, who will soon mark the anniversary of their strike, to (ask them to) refrain from destabilizing further the situation in the Russian Federation,'' Yeltsin said. He said the situation ``is heated so much that any spark, any irresponsible action or even a word, could create a fire.'' The Soviet Union is plagued by ethnic strife among many of its more than 100 nationalities, chronic shortages of consumer goods and food, rampant crime and poverty. Yeltsin has appeared almost nightly on TV for the past few weeks in broadcasts of proceedings from the Congress of People's Deputies of the Russian Federation. But Saturday's interview was the first time he was allowed a special broadcast to espouse his views. Yeltsin was elected president of the Russian Federation, which comprises two-thirds of the country's territory and just over half its population, last month. At his urging, the Russian Congress on Friday passed a ``Declaration of Sovereignty.'' It proclaims that Russian laws take precedence over national legislation. In Saturday's interview, Yeltsin promised his economic reform program would ``help our people to live better.'' Without giving details, he said the program will hurt people less than the central government's plan to raise prices starting July 1 in its transition to a ``regulated market economy.'' Turning from the interviewer seated across a glass-topped table to look directly into the camera, he added, ``We need some credit of faith, dear comrades, from you for two years, maybe a little more _ two or three years maximum _ to stabilize the situation and improve generally the situation in the Russsian Federation.'' And reassuring skeptics, he added, ``Such a program exists. It's not just words.'' Yeltsin, in the television interview recorded Thursday, said his reformist forces have only a shaky majority and said he might have to turn directly to the people if parliament failed to adopt his radical measures. ``If there is a critical point of a lack of understanding, I will appeal to the people,'' Yeltsin said.

DOC.HEAD: Fireboats Having Little Effect on Raging Tanker Fire
With AM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
LaserColor HT6, LaserPhoto HT5
DOC.TEXT: Balls of flame spewed Saturday from the aft section of the burning supertanker Mega Borg, sending huge columns of black smoke high over the Gulf of Mexico. The smoke was visible for some 40 miles, leaving a cloud thousands of feet in the mostly sunny sky. From a helicopter above the scene, heat from the blaze was intense and could be felt several hundred feet above the burning ship. The air smelled of burning fuel. Three streams of water from a pair of fireboats appeared to have little effect on the inferno. Two Coast Guard cutters cruised nearby. A motorized rubber boat patrolled near the bow of the burning ship. Two crewmen were confirmed dead in the 1 a.m. explosion and authorities said two others were missing and presumed dead. Of the crew of 41, 18 crew members were injured, none seriously, officials said. The Coast Guard said the 853-foot Mega Borg was hauling about 38 million gallons of light crude oil when the blast occurred, 57 miles southeast of Galveston. The fire continued to rage out of control Saturday afternoon, as two fireboats sprayed jets of water on the flames. Fire poured from the tanker's stack and engulfed the aft section, including the wheelhouse, accounting for about the back fifth of the ship. Sections of the crew quarters that weren't in flames were charred black. Blackened sections extended far up the walls and nearly to a radar antenna. One fireboat, the Carolyn Chouest, was a few yards off the stern of the Mega Borg, shooting two streams, one directly down the stack and another in the flaming quarters on the starboard aft. A second, smaller fireboat was moored to the burning ship and played a single stream into the flames. There was no sign of activity aboard the ship, which did not appear to be listing. The rear section appeared somewhat lower in the water than the rest of the maroon-colored vessel. There also was no evidence in the water around the ship that it was leaking cargo. A small black oil slick could be seen to the left of the bow continuing about one-third of the way along the water line. It did not appear to be growing. The remains of a flag, now ragged and charred black, blew in the wind off a mast on the stern of the ship.

DOC.HEAD: Czechoslovak Scandal Stems From Communist Era
With AM-Czechoslovakia, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The country's first free election in 44 years should have been a joyous celebration of democracy, but it has been marred by the legacy of its Communist past. The charges and counter-charges over purported links between People's Party Chairman Josef Bartoncik and the Communists are the latest illustration of how the atmosphere of suspicion spawned by decades of authoritarian rule can poison the climate of emerging Eastern European democraties. In Bartoncik's case, opponents have charged he collaborated for 17 years with the Communists' dreaded STB secret police. He has denied wrongdoing. Interior Minister Richard Sacher, also a member of the Bartoncik's non-Communist party, asserted Saturday that no evidence has been presented to back up the accusations. Thousands of files listing STB informants were destroyed in the aftermath of the peaceful November revolution that overturned Communist domination. Bartoncik's accusers say documents relating to Bartoncik appear to have been among them. But the staff of President Vaclav Havel asserts Bartoncik did not deny his informer role when confronted by Havel, a former dissident who enjoys unrivaled popularity because of his courageous defiance of Communist authorities. Other leading government personalities associated with Havel's Civic Forum political movement say Bartoncik figures on a list of former STB informers. Civic Forum, which led the fight against Communist rule with its sister party Public Against Violence, was founded by dissidents who suffered most under the autocratic Marxists. The post-Communist government has announced the dismantling of the secret police. However, fear and suspicion bred by decades of persecution contribute to the search for past culprits. The increasingly acrimonious dispute pitting the two anti-Communist parties could breed distrust for years to come. ``I have great doubts about the future development in this country. It reminds me too much of the past years,'' said Jiri Cerny, general-secretary of Bartoncik's party. In a protest to the National Electoral Commission, People's Party leaders on Saturday claimed the timing of accusations against Bartoncik violated a rule prohibiting campaigning 48 hours before the voting, which began Friday and finished Saturday.. They left open whether they would ask that the elections be invalidated _ a move that would further tarnish Czechoslovakia's democratic rebirth. Other East European nations have suffered similar problems as they emerged from totalitarianism. In East Germany, Wolfgang Schnur, a top conservative candidate, admitted four days before free elections March 18 that he had at one time worked for the secret police. He then resigned. Ibrahim Boehme gave up his post as chairman of East Germany's Social Democrats after unproven allegations he had also worked for the ``Stasi'' secret police. The democratic climate is perhaps most poisoned in Romania, whose swift and bloody December revolution left the Securitate secret police formally in shambles but many of its personnel unscathed. The Communist Party also collapsed, but many of its former functionaries are members of the new government. A protest of those Communist links was in its 48th day Saturday in downtown Bucharest. Even in Hungary, where the ruling party voluntarily held multiparty elections and agreed to yield power, the Communist legacy has cast a long shadow. The biggest scandal in the weeks before the March elections were revelations that surviving elements from the secret police were spying on anti-Communist parties.

DOC.HEAD: Wellsburg Celebrates End of Two-Year Wellness Program
DOC.TEXT: People who spent two years trying to lower their weight, fat, cholesterol, and blood pressure celebrated the end of the wellness program on Saturday with a healthy brunch. The private project to improve rural Americans' cardiovascular health resulted in an average 8.6-pound loss of body fat as well as reduced cholesterol and blood pressure, organizers said. About 300 people gathered for the farewell meal of a lean turkey sandwich, oat bran muffins, fruit, smoked salmon and asparagus. Results of a final health screening done late last month showed that the 517 people who were in the program from start to finish saw their cholesterol drop from 220.4 to 208.4, an average of 5.4 percent, according to program director Bill Reger. Average blood pressures fell from 131.5 over 81.3 to 126.2 over 78.3, Reger said. A blood pressure of 120 over 80 is considered ideal, according to the National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute. Participants also lost an average of 3.5 pounds in total weight and 8.6 pounds of body fat, according to organizers. ``The media used to call us `fat city,''' said Reger. ``Now they recognize that we're the state of the art of wellness.'' Study participants were encouraged to follow a low-fat, high-fiber diet, exercise and use stress-management techniques. Free cooking and aerobics classes were offered along with lectures on heart disease, nutrition and weight loss. Clinics also were offered to help smokers kick the habit. The study, begun in May 1988, was sponsored by The Bayer Co., and Glenbrook Laboratories, the aspirin maker's New York-based parent. Sen. Jay Rockefeller, D-W.Va., and Bayer President Richard F. Gaccione offered their encouragement at Saturday's farewell brunch. Rockefeller said $600 billion is spent in the United States annually on health care, with a large portion directly related to unhealthy lifestyles. Gaccione presented a $30,000 grant to the newly created Brooke County Wellness, Inc., a nonprofit corporation established to keep the program going in the area. Rockefeller added a $1,000 donation.

DOC.HEAD: Mooring Line Snaps and Injures Five
DOC.TEXT: A mooring line snapped and injured five men, one critically, as they were securing an oil tanker offshore Saturday, said Coast Guard officials. The men were working on the 780-foot OMI Columbia just off the coast of Marina Del Rey when the mooring line snapped, said Elizabeth Neely, a Coast Guard spokeswoman. ``A snapped mooring line has the recoil force of a fired weapon,'' Neely said. A Coast Guard helicopter airlifted four of the men to Harbor-UCLA Medical Center and another to a hospital in nearby Torrance, Neely said. The critically injured man had a broken leg and head injuries, officials said. His condition was later upgraded to stable and three others were released from the hospital, said Sharon Ellis, nursing supervisor at Harbor-UCLA. The condition of the fifth man was not immediately available. None of the victims were identified. The ship was not damaged.

DOC.HEAD: Former Radio Minister Pleads Innocent
DOC.TEXT: A former radio minister was allowed to remain free without bail after pleading innocent to federal charges of defrauding listeners who donated money for a youth camp. Troy Cecil Snowden, whose ``The Troy Snowden Ministry'' was broadcast from October 1986 to 1988, is accused in a federal indictment of fraudulently using his radio ministry to obtain property and illegal sex with a minor. The indictment alleged that Snowden used his late-night call-in show on radio station KAAY to solicit contributions to the Troy Snowden Ministry and Lion of Judah Youth Ranch. The contributions were received at a post office box in North Little Rock. The four-count indictment did not say how much money Snowden allegedly defrauded from listeners. Snowden, 46, allegedly told listeners that contributions were to be invested in the construction of a youh ranch in West Plains, Mo. He was arrested in Fort Myers Beach, Fla., on May 24, but has been free on a $100,000 unsecured bond. U.S. Magistrate Henry L. Jones Jr. allowed Snowden to remain free after Snowden entered his plea Friday in U.S. District Court. Following his arrest, Snowden appeared before Jones, and said he couldn't afford to hire a lawyer to defend him. ``I ain't got nothing now,'' he said when questioned about his financial condition. ``I had a chance at some (money), but I was arrested.'' Jones appointed lawyer Marva Davis of Little Rock to represent Snowden. Jones then accepted Snowden's innocent plea to the indictment. A jury trial was set for July 9 with U.S. District Judge Elsijane T. Roy presiding. The bond also stipulated that Snowden could have no contact with the girl he was accused of taking from Jacksonville, Ark., to Arizona and Hattiesburg, Miss., in early 1989 to engage in sexual activity when she was 14. ``We originally asked for detention,'' said Assistant U.S. Attorney Lesa Jackson. She said the request was based on the risk Snowden might leave the United States and his danger to the community. Jackson, however, said the U.S. Justice Department had no objection to Snowden's release on certain conditions. Among them were that he be ordered to have no contact with about 10 other people associated with the case, stay off the KAAY radio station property in Little Rock and refrain from any additional fund raising.

DOC.HEAD: Religion Writers from Los Angeles, St. Petersburg Papers Win Awards
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT name to `Sopalski,' sted `Sodalski.'
DOC.TEXT: Religion reporters of the Los Angeles Times and the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Times were named winners of the top 1989 awards of the Religion Newswriters Association at its annual meeting Saturday. Russell Chandler of the Los Angeles Times won the $2,500 John Templeton Reporter of the Year award for the third time. Michelle Bearden of the St. Petersburg Times won the $500 James O. Supple Memorial Award, for distinguished religion writing. Don Lattin of the San Francisco Chronicle won second place in both the Templeton and Supple competitions. The association includes about 200 specialists who cover religion for the secular press. Joan Connell of the San Jose Mercury News in California accepted the Harold Schachern Memorial Award for the outstanding religion section. Second place went to the St. Petersburg Times and third to the Arizona Republic. Tom Price of the Elkhart (Ind.) Truth received the Louis Cassels Memorial Award for religion writing on newspapers with a circulation of 50,000 or fewer. Runners up were Steve Brunsman of the Biloxi (Miss.) Sun-Herald, second, and Julia Sopalski of the Anchorage (Alaska) Times, third.

DOC.HEAD: Showers from Eastern Pennsylvania to Southern New England
DOC.TEXT: Showers and thunderstorms extended from eastern Pennsylvania to southern New England, and strong northwesterly winds brought cooler air to the upper Great Lakes region and the middle Mississippi Valley. A few showers fell over northern Maine. Rain developed across Florida and along the Gulf Coast, and over the central Appalachians. Showers and thunderstorms extended from the Texas Panhandle to northern Oklahoma, and developed over eastern Arkansas, western Tennessee and northern Mississippi. They also formed over Colorado and New Mexico. West of the Rockies, scattered showers and thunderstorms developed over Southern California and southern Arizona and scattered rain fell along the northern Pacific Coast. Skies were sunny from the northern Rockies to the upper Great Lakes, and from Texas to the central Gulf Coast states. Temperatures were in the 80s and lower 90s across the southern and central Plains region. Readings were only in the 60s and upper 50s along the northern Atlantic Coast and across northern sections of the upper Great Lakes. In the West, temperatures varied from the 50s along the northern Pacific Coast to the 90s in the Southwestern deserts. The low temperature for the Lower 48 states was 31 degrees at West Yellowstone, Mont.

DOC.HEAD: Havel And Fellow Dissidents Look Set For Election Victory
LaserColor PRA1,3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS thruout with one anti-Communist leader quitting after admitting ties to secret police; RAISES projections; UPDATES with Havel at concerts; TRIMS pvs; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Vaclav Havel and the other dissidents who toppled the Communists late last year appeared headed for a solid victory Saturday in the nation's first free elections in 44 years. But a dispute over top politicians who allegedly worked for the Communist secret police clouded the election euphoria. Havel's aides, at a nationally televised news conference, accused a top Christian Democrat leader of working for the dreaded STB secret police for 17 years. In a related development, a Havel ally and leader of the anti-Communist revolution, Jan Budaj, announced at an emotional evening news conference that he had worked for the secret police and was quitting politics. The national election was essentially a contest between two anti-Communist alliances: Civic Forum and its sister party, Public Against Violence; and the Christian Democratic Union. Projections released 4{ hours after polls closed and based on initial vote counts suggested that Havel's Civic Forum and Public Against Violence, who together helped topple Communist rule, had won about 50 percent of the votes in the federal parliament. The Christian Democrat Union, which may have been hurt by the charges about its leader, had about 12 percent of the vote in both chambers, running virtually neck and neck with the Communists. The People's Party, led by the accused man, Josef Bartoncik, lodged a formal complaint that Havel's government violated election laws by denouncing Bartoncik less than 48 hours before balloting started. The People's Party is part of the Christian Democrat Union's coalition. International observers monitoring voting on Friday and Saturday did not say whether they believed the scandal violated election laws. The Czechoslovak commission overseeing the elections ruled that a violation had occurred, but it was not clear what action would be taken. Bartoncik was expected to win a seat in the new federal Parliament, and the dispute over his background could become important if the election results in a coalition government. In the Slovak capital of Bratislava, Budaj, a leader of Public Against Violence, said he was pressured into signing a document in 1979 to cooperate with the secret police after trying to defect and getting caught. The election was for a 300-seat, bicameral federal Parliament, which will draft a new constitution removing the last vestiges of Communist rule. The lawmakers also are expected to re-elect Havel to a two-year term. Czechoslovaks also voted during the two-day election for regional parliaments for the Czech and Slovak republics. Final results were not expected until Sunday. The Parliament is made up of the House of the People, whose 150 members ran at large nationwide, and the House of Nations, whose 150 members represent either the Czech or the Slovak republics. Other smaller parties were trying to win the 5 percent minimum vote required to get seats under a system of proportional representation. Top aides to Havel interrupted a nationally televised news conference for the first TV broadcast of the initial projections. The aides beamed as the projections came through, and Havel's spokesman, Michael Zantovsky, made a V-sign to applauding Czech supporters. But the aides faced tough questions about their handling of the Bartoncik affair. Allegations that Bartoncik was a secret police agent first surfaced in May in the Austrian weekly Profil. It said he worked under the code name ``Hajek'' and registration number 15301 in the Moravian capital, Brno, where he was a top official of his party, then allied with the Communists. Bartoncik denied any collaboration with the hated STB, or secret police. His party colleague, Interior Minister Richard Sacher, earlier had come under fire for alleged reluctance to investigate secret police activities. Sacher's deputy, Jan Ruml, a Havel appointee and like the president a former dissident, was then charged with investigating STB operations. Ruml told Saturday's news conference that he had confirmed only on Monday that Bartoncik's name was on a register of Brno secret police agents. ``For 17 years, he was a paid adviser of the STB,'' said Havel aide Jiri Krizan. Prosecutor Pavel Rychetsky said a former STB agent had come forward independently to him on Tuesday and told him that the information Bartoncik gathered was passed directly to former party leader Milos Jakes. Bartoncik even infiltrated the dissident movement Charter 77, Rychetsky said, building contacts with Vaclav Benda, now the leader of the Czech Christian Democrats. Havel confronted Bartoncik with the information on Tuesday and Bartoncik promised to quit politics, said Krizan, who was present at the meeting. Bartoncik was hosptalized late Tuesday with a reported heart attack, but issued no statement that he was relinquishing his candidacy for parliament. More than 100 people from all parties did step down after screening for links with the secret police, who Civic Forum says had a network of 140,000 informers. Later Saturday, Havel broke away from the political disputes to appear as the non-musical star of a concert to denounce racism. The president, who took the stage to welcome American singer Paul Simon,was himself greeted by wild cheers of ``Long Live Havel!'' from a crowd of about 10,000 at the concert in Prague's historic Old Town Square. Havel said the concert ``is even more special because it's taking place on the day when after long decades we could again choose our future.''

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Guerrillas Captured Close to Israeli Border
DOC.TEXT: Israeli-allied militiamen Saturday captured three Palestinian guerrillas as they tried to infiltrate into northern Israel, the army said. The military said a routine patrol of the South Lebanon Army militia spotted the three-man squad moving towards Israel about 2 miles north of the border settlement of Misgav Am. The army said the guerrillas were Palestinians, but gave no other details of their identities. The infiltration attempt was the first reported since the Israeli army foiled an attempt by seaborne guerrillas from the Palestine Liberation Front to land at a beachfront south of Tel Aviv on May 30. The Palestine group is a faction of the Palestine Liberation Organization. The United States is considering an end to its dialogue with the PLO due to the failed raid. Also Saturday, the Syrian-backed Shiite Moslem Amal militia killed a Lebanese man in the southern port city of Tyre accused of collaborating with Israel. An Amal gunman shot 26-year-old Haidar al-Asmar as he sat on a rock blindfolded with his hands and legs tied. More than 3,000 people watched the killing, local reporters said. Asmar was a Lebanese army soldier from the village of Yareen inside Israel's self-proclaimed security zone in southern Lebanon. Amal sources said militiamen arrested Asmar on Tuesday after he shot and seriously wounded a travel agent in Tyre. One source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Amal militiamen chased Asmar and captured him 1,800 feet outside the security zone. Israel carved out a two-to-10-mile wide buffer zone in southern Lebanon in 1985 after it withdrew the bulk of its forces from Lebanon following its 1982 invasion. About 3,000 South Lebanon Army militiamen, backed by about 1,000 Israeli troops, patrol the zone.

DOC.HEAD: Court Adjourns Hearing on Trial of Nasser's Son
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto CAI1
DOC.TEXT: A state security court adjourned until Sunday the trial of the eldest son of the late President Gamal Abdel Nasser and 19 others accused of attacks on U.S. and Israeli diplomats. Judge Emad el-Din Ismail of the state security court adjourned Saturday's session after hearing an attorney defending the leader of the group that claimed responsibility for the attacks. Ismail said he will continue to hear arguments from the defense attorney Sunday. Two of the heads of the Egypt's Revolution group, Mahmoud Nour el-Din el-Sayed Ali Suliman, and Khaled Gamal Abdel Nasser, a 40-year-old engineer and son of Egypt's former socialist president, have been charged with leading the attacks. The two, along with nine other defendants, face the death penalty if convicted. Khaled Nasser returned to Egypt on Wednesday and gave himself up to police at Cairo International Airport, saying he intended to prove himself innocent. Nasser and another 19 members of the Egypt's Revolution group are accused of four terror attacks against Israeli and American diplomats between 1984 and 1987. The attacks killed two Israelis and wounded six Israelis and two Americans.
