DOC.BYLINE: Children of Political Figures Wed in Union Dubbed ``Cuomolot'' ^By LEE BYRD
DOC.TEXT: Kerry Kennedy and Andrew Cuomo were married Saturday in a ceremony that merged two of America's most powerful political families. They swore mutual commitment to the oppressed _ ``the people who have disappeared in El Salvador, the children in shelters in New York.'' The bride, 30, is the daughter of the late Robert F. Kennedy and is executive director the human rights center in New York City which bears his name. The groom, 32, is the New York Gov. Mario Cuomo's son and chief political adviser; he currently heads a Manhattan foundation to help the homeless. The elaborate, closed wedding, attended by 300 people, was at the Cathedral of St. Matthew, a Catholic church about a half-mile from the White House and the one where President John F. Kennedy's funeral was held in 1963. Kerry Kennedy, the late president's niece, was just 3 years old when he was assassinated, just 8 when her father was gunned down. She was the seventh of Robert and Ethel Kennedy's children. The bride walked the aisle alone as the entire Kennedy clan, including Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis, and a planeload of Cuomo relatives and intimates looked on. The guest list remained secret, but it included New York Mayor David Dinkins, film maker Francis Ford Coppola, newspaper columnists Jimmy Breslin and Art Buchwald and dozens of others who occupied a swarm of photographers and hundreds of sightseers who lined the sidewalk across from the church. Kerry Kennedy's cousin, Maria Shriver, the groom's father, and several brothers and sisters of both the bride and groom gave readings during the wedding mass, celebrated by the Rev. Gerard C. Creedon of County Cork, Ireland, a longtime Kennedy family friend now performing Catholic charity work in nearby Alexandria, Va. Creedon said the couple affirmed a pledge to uphold ``family traditions, and their commitment to human rights and justice.'' He charged them in the ceremony, at their request, to always ``cherish the people who have disappeared in El Salvador, the children in shelters in New York.'' Kerry Kennedy wore a Scaasi-designed dress of gleaming silk white satin with a basque bodice, a sweetheart neckline, puff sleeves, a voluminous skirt and a cathedral train. It was ornamented with crystals, silver bugle beads and hearts of pearl. The groom and his 15-member party wore morning suits. The maids of honor were Kerry's younger sister, Rory, 21, and friend Mary Richardson, 30. Sisters Courtney Kennedy and Kathleen Kennedy Townsend were among 13 maids of honor. Andrew Cuomo's younger brother, Christopher, 19, was best man. Ushers included brothers-in-law Kenneth Cole and Robert Perpignano, and Kerry's brothers, Christopher, Douglas, Rep. Joseph P. Kennedy III, D-Mass., Max, Michael and Robert Jr. The bride carried a cascade of white roses, lisianthus, stephinotis, gardenias, sweet peas and bouvardia. Her attendants held bouquets of pink florabunda roses and sweet peas, and her flower girls wore halos of baby roses. The coupled drew warm cheers and applause as they emerged from the hour-plus ceremony. And cries of ``Jackie, Jackie, Jackie'' greeted John Kennedy's widow, dressed in an all-white business suit. A three-abreast, block-long flotilla of stretch limousines then carried the wedding party and virtually all their guests to a reception at Hickory Hill, the McLean, Va., home of Ethel Kennedy, the bride's mother. The ceremony blended classical and African-American music, and featured Ruth Brown, the star soloist of New York's ``Black and Blue.'' The wedding had been informally billed as the creation of ``Cuomolot,'' a successor to the fabled land of Camelot so revered by John F. Kennedy. But friends and family alike pleaded for an abatement of any political speculations. ``This isn't the Middle Ages where the Duke of Normandy and the Duke of Avignon get together and decide on a marriage,'' said William Cunningham, an adviser to Gov. Cuomo, a day earlier. ``This is not a dynastic accomplishment, this is two people who decided to get married.'' But Frank Mankiewicz, former press secretary to Robert F. Kennedy, wrying observed that if a new dynasty emerges, ``It's got awful good bloodlines. It's like they say in baseball _ it's one of those trades that helps both clubs.'' Both Andrew Cuomo and Kerry Kennedy Cuomo are law-school graduates. They had dated for nearly two years before he offered her a diamond ring last Valentine's day. She is graduate of Brown University and Boston College Law School. He is a graduate of Fordham University and Albany Law School. Cuomo has worked for his father's political campaigns since he was a teen-ager, and managed his gubernatorial victories in 1982 and 1986. He plans to run his father's campaign for re-election this year as well. Following a six-day honeymoon in the Caribbean, the couple plans to settle in Queens, N.Y. Andrew Cuomo's current office, as head of HELP, the non-profit corporation to build temporary housing for the homeless, is in Manhattan. Seven years ago, a family biographer asked Kerry Kennedy what she hoped her life would be like in 10 years. She replied: ``I want to be married and madly in love and have a million children. I want to be working hard and my husband working hard and I want both of us to be involved in something caring and constructive. Something we can put our hearts and souls into.''

DOC.HEAD: Oil Spill Fouls New York Beaches
With AM-Tanker Blast
DOC.TEXT: Oil that spilled from a grounded tanker into a busy shipping channel between New York City and New Jersey fouled about four miles of city and national beaches Saturday, officials said. Workers removed about 800 pounds of tar balls that began washing up Friday night along 2\ miles of Midland Beach on the borough of Staten Island, said James Cafaro, supervisor of city beaches on the borough. The 260,000-gallon spill occurred Thursday morning when the 811-foot tanker BT Nautilus ran aground in the Kill Van Kull waterway. At the Great Kills unit of the Gateway National Recreation Area, which borders Midland Beach, an ``extensive washup'' of oil hit 1{ to 2 miles of beach, said Gateway spokesman Manny Strumpf. Both beaches remained open Saturday, spokesmen said. Tar balls were spotted as far away as Coney Island, about three nautical miles from the spill site. Park rangers also removed 40 pounds of tar balls from a section of beach at Breezy Point in Queens, another unit of Gateway, Strumpf said. Gateway's other federal beach, Sandy Hook in New Jersey, has not been affected, Strumpf said. The cleanup of the spill Saturday involved more than 420 workers, skimming boats, vacuum trucks and about 80 other boats, officials said. By Saturday morning, more than 10,000 gallons of the No. 6 heating oil had been recovered, said Coast Guard Lt. Cmdr. Paul A. Milligan. Two Navy skimming boats arrived from Norfolk, Va., and worked the adjacent Arthur Kill on Saturday, authorities said. Two sensitive nesting areas in the vicinity, Pralls Island and Shooters Island, had booms placed around them Thursday. A Coast Guard board of inquiry is to begin hearings Monday on the grounding of the British-owned tanker and other incidents that since the first of the year have dumped more than 1 million gallons of oil into the waters of New York harbor, four times the amount spilled last year, the Coast Guard said. Separate investigations by the Coast Guard, New Jersey and New York are under way. The first mate of the BT Nautilus, Geoffrey Frederick Gregory of England, was charged Thursday by New Jersey authorities with operating a vessel under the influence of alcohol or drugs. The Kill Van Kull could be reopened to shipping on Sunday, said Milligan. The waterway was closed after the grounding and was reopened on a case-by-case basis Friday afternoon. Three dead birds have been found, the Coast Guard said. A cleaning station established in Bayonne by Toms River Avian, a volunteer rescue group, has treated some birds, said John Hagerty, a spokesman for the state Department of Environmental Protection, but he could not provide numbers. ``They are saying the impact on the avian population is minimal,'' said Hagerty. ``We're in a migratory period so there aren't that many birds in the area.''

DOC.HEAD: New President Will Inherit Violent, Bankrupt Country
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to UPDATE with Shining Path guerrilla call to boycott elections. Pickup 5th pvs, `Fujimori, 51...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LIM1
DOC.TEXT: The presidential candidate voters choose Sunday to lead Peru through the next five years will inherit a violent, bankrupt country many people believe is ungovernable. Whatever the campaign promises, long-brewing crises will make it difficult just to maintain current levels of poverty and popular discontent. On the eve of the election, Maoist Shining Path guerrillas called ``armed strikes'' in four important cities in the Andean highlands and the eastern jungle region to block the voting. The call, issued in pamphlets, crudely painted wall posters and messages to radio station, carried with it the threat of violence against those disobeying the order to boycott the election. Those voting will decide between novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, a conservative champion of free markets, and Alberto Fujimori, the son of Japanese immigrants, who was an obscure agricultural engineer when the presidential campaign began. Fujimori, 51, and Vargas Llosa, 54, were in a dead heat in the runoff election, according to independent polls released Friday. By law President Alan Garcia can't run for a consecutive five-year term. ``It's a fallacy to say this country is ungovernable,'' Fujimori, an independent, said in an interview. ``The country is governable, but the political parties have demonstrated they're incapable of governing.'' About 10 million of the 22 million Peruvians are eligible to vote, and are required by law to do so. Polls will be open from 8 a.m. to 3 p.m. If it is a close contest, as expected, the result may not be known for weeks because of poor communications with isolated mountain and jungle towns. The runoff was required after no candidate received a majority in the first round of balloting April 8. The winner is to take office July 28. Among his problems will be: _Annual inflation of 2,000 percent. The inti, worth 7 cents when it was introduced in 1986, has shrunk to less than two-thousandths of a penny. Wages have lost 50 percent of their purchasing power in the past two years. _Two leftist insurgencies. Political violence takes nine lives a day and at least 18,500 have been killed in the last decade. The economic damage is more than $15 billion, rebels control large parts of the interior and one-third of Peru is under military control. _A foreign debt of $20 billion, the highest per capita in South America. International agencies stopped credit when Peru ceased making payments on the debt in 1986, and several foreign banks are suing. The treasury is more than $100 million in the red. _Labor and public unrest. Street sweepers, prison inmates, even hospital patients hold strikes and protests for higher pay and better services. Four of five Peruvians lack regular employment. _Drug trafficking. Peru is the largest producer of coca leaf, the raw material of cocaine, and more than 200,000 Peruvians make their living from it. The international crackdown on trafficking has cut into the $1 billion the country earns annually from the trade, and the United States is pressing Peru to accept military aid in fighting coca production. _Destroyed or worn-out public facilities. Major highways are crumbling for lack of maintenance, crippling the transport of produce from farms in the interior. Guerrillas blow up bridges and power lines. Power and water rationing hamper industrial production. Natural disasters have done their share of damage. An earthquake devastated towns in the northern jungle last month, and a volcano in the southern Andes is threatening to erupt. Scientists have detected the beginnings of an El Nino phenomenon, unusually warm ocean currents that disrupt weather patterns. A 1982 El Nino ruined crops and nearly destroyed the important fishing industry. A recent Rand Corp. study financed partly by the U.S. State Department said a military takeover was imminent. ``Conditions will become much worse before they get better,'' it said. ``The real question is not whether there will be a coup, but when.'' The general belief in Peru appears to be that a Fujimori victory would be more likely to provoke a coup because of his economic plans. Critics say they differ little from the populist measures of President Garcia. Among Fujimori's stated goals are reducing annual inflation to less than 100 percent by the end of his first year. He advocates maintaining controls on the economy, which Vargas Llosa blames for Peru's economic decline, and says he will replace the inti with a new currency. Fujimori proposes allowing prices for subsidized goods and services to reach market levels, but then would freeze wages and prices for six months. He also promises to reach agreement with foreign lenders on new credits. He has rejected help from the U.S. military with the anti-drug campaign and proposes to wean farmers from coca by stimulating production of legal crops. Vargas Llosa's inflation goal is 10 percent within a year, and he wants fundamental changes in the economy based on free-market principles. The novelist would reduce the huge bureaucracy by ``shifting'' tens of thousands of workers to the private sector. He proposes lifting price controls, selling state enterprises and changing labor laws to allow companies to fire unproductive workers.

DOC.HEAD: Freely-Elected Parliament Meets For First Time
DOC.TEXT: Presided over by its eldest members, Romania's first freely-elected Parliament in more than half a century met Saturday in buildings once used by ousted Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The 119-member Senate, which met in Omnia Hall in downtown Bucharest, and the 396-member Chamber of Deputies, which met at the Parliament building about a mile away, both agreed on preliminary rules of procedure. Outside Parliament, some 300 anti-government demonstrators chanted ``Down with Communism!'' and demanded the resignation of President-elect Ion Iliescu, who won a landslide victory in Romania's May 20 elections. Inside the Senate, legislator Cezar Buda said: ``This first working day of the Senate is to us all a historic moment indeed.'' Buda, who at 82 was the oldest senator, was chosen to preside over the inaugural meeting. He is from the opposition National Liberal Party. He said the first task of the two-chamber Parliament was to draft a new constitution. In the lower chamber, Rene-Radu Policrat, also a Liberal and at 80 the oldest deputy, said: ``We are again masters of our destinies now ... Out of all dictatorships, the dictatorship that could rule would be the dictatorship of liberty.'' The Provisional Council, established after December's revolution that toppled Ceausescu, passed an electoral law abolishing Romania's unicameral legislator and instituted the two-house Parliament that was first adopted by the nation in 1886. Iliescu's National Salvation Front, a broad coalition of workers, peasants and technocrats, won two-thirds of the seats in the Chamber of Deputies and about 77 percent of the Senate in the May 20 election. The Hungarian Democratic Party is the largest opposition party followed by the Liberals. Of Romania's 119 senators, as many as 115 were present at the meeting in Omnia Hall, which was once used to host the Communist Party's plenary meetings.

DOC.HEAD: South Korean Students Fight Police During Demonstrations
DOC.TEXT: Radical students and dissidents fought riot police Saturday in street battles around Seoul and the southern city of Kwangju during demonstrations to demand broader democratic reform. Radical groups had called for nationwide protests against the government of President Roh Tae-woo in Seoul and 17 other cities this weekend to mark the anniversary of 1987 pro-democracy protests. However, that call went largely unheeded Saturday. Radicals vowed to stage more protests in 18 cities Sunday. In 1987, the nationwide popular protests reached their peak on June 10 as tens of thousands of students and other South Koreans rose up against the dictatorial President Chun Doo-hwan, demanding democratic reform. Chun finally agreed to hold the country's first direct presidential elections later that year. Roh won as the government candidate. He has since introduced widespread democratic reform, including greater press freedom, but critics say he has not done enough. Roh's popularity has declined recently, but most South Koreans also shun the radicals because of their violent tactics. On Saturday, about half the country's 130,000-member national police force was mobilized to block protests, officials said. In Seoul, about 2,000 students, in groups ranging from 200 to 500, clashed with police at at least five different places, hurling rocks and firebombs. Police fired tear gas to break up the protesters. ``Punish Roh Tae-woo!'' demonstrators shouted, charging that the general-turned-president was backtracking on his promise of reform. ``Disband the DLP!'' protesters also chanted, accusing Roh's governing Democratic Liberal Party of scheming to prolong what they called ``dictatorial power.'' The party, formed through a merger of Roh's old governing party with two centrist opposition groups, has become a main target of student protests. Students say the consolidated party will stifle democracy. In southern Seoul, police fired tear gas to disperse about 200 members of a leading dissident group, the National Democratic Alliance, who were trying to demonstrate near Kuro Industrial Complex. Police arrested about 50 people, including Chang Ki-pyo, chief organizer of the alliance. In the southern opposition stronghold of Kwangju, 150 miles south of Seoul, about 300 radical students attacked a district office of Roh's party with firebombs, the Yonhap news agency said. The students fled when police moved in with tear gas, the agency said. No injuries were reported in the clashes.

DOC.HEAD: Burlington Northern Freight, Maintenance Unit Crash `Like a Sonic Boom'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The westbound ...,' to CORRECT that freight train was traveling east, rail grinder west.
DOC.TEXT: A head-on collision between a freight train and a large rail-maintenance unit caused a spectacular fire, more than $500,000 in damage and the 12-hour shutdown of an Amtrak passenger route, officials said. Braking problems on a rail grinder, a heavy unit about two locomotives long that was being operated by a contractor, apparently led to the accident Friday evening, Howard Kallio of Burlington Northern Railroad said Saturday. All three locomotives and some of the approximately 35 cars on the freight train were destroyed, Kallio said. He estimated damage at $530,000 to the engines, cars and tracks. Firefighters battled flames that sent up a column of smoke visible five miles. Four workers suffered minor injuries in the crash, hospital officials said. The eastbound freight train was traveling about 50 mph when the collision occurred, while the rail grinder pulling 10 cars was westbound at about 20 mph, Kallio said. They crashed when the rail grinder failed to stop before a point where two sets of track converge, he said. Crew members were given urinalysis tests as required under federal law, but ``it appears that (the grinder) must have lost some braking capacity,'' he said. Kallio said he did not know the extent of damage to the rail grinder, used once or twice a year on heavily traveled tracks to remove rough spots from the top and sides of the rails. Passengers from two trains _ one westbound and one eastbound _ were bused between Wenatchee and Spokane before the tracks were reopened between 6 a.m. and 7 a.m. Saturday, he said. About 20 residents were evacuated briefly from homes about a mile from the crash site.

DOC.HEAD: Paintings Recovered Two Years After City's Largest Art Theft
DOC.TEXT: Fourteen of 19 Old Masters paintings stolen from a gallery more than two years ago in what police said was the city's largest art theft have been recovered, the gallery's director said. No one has been arrested in the $6 million burglary, Nicholas Hall, director of the Colnaghi USA Ltd. gallery on Manhattan's Upper East Side, said Friday. He refused to provide further details, saying the case remained open. The 14 paintings were recovered Monday, Hall said. Nine Old Masters drawings that were also stolen have not been recovered. The most valuable pieces recovered were two 15-by-7-inch wood panels by the 15th century Italian Renaissance master Fra Angelico, Hall said. The panels, depicting saints, were worth a combined $4 million. ``One is talking about one of the crucial artists of the early Florentine Renaissance,'' Hall said. He said the number of works by Fra Angelico outside Italy is extremely small. Hall said the recovered panels appeared to be in good condition. ``Only cosmetic work will be needed to fix them,'' he said. The paintings and drawings were taken on Feb. 8, 1988, by thieves who broke in through a skylight in the gallery on the Upper East Side.

DOC.HEAD: Church Leaders Say Peace Talks Organized
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 18 grafs to UPDATE with U.S. comment, RAISE that there is no truce. Pickup 15th pvs, `Government officials...'
DOC.TEXT: The government and rebels who have been closing in on the capital have agreed to attend peace talks mediated by the Liberian Council of Churches, the government and rebels said Saturday. However, there was no cease-fire reported in the country's civil war. The church council also has asked the United States to send troops to Liberia as a peacekeeping force, council president Levee Moulton said. A U.S. official late Saturday said he had no information on such a request. The United States has refused President Samuel Doe's request for military assistance, saying Marines would be sent in only if hostilities reach the capital and endanger Americans. It has four warships with 2,100 Marines stationed off the coast. The rebels, led by former bureaucrat Charles Taylor, had consistently refused to negotiate unless Doe resigns and leaves Liberia. But a rebel spokesman, Eric Dukaleu, in a telephone interview late Saturday from the Ivory Coast city of Man, near the border with Liberia, said the rebels would attend. A government source, who declined to be identified further, said the peace talks will begin Monday at the U.S. Embassy in Freetown in neighboring Sierra Leone. Government radio confirmed Doe had agreed to send a delegation. A statement issued by the church council made no mention of the cease-fire it has been calling for in the 5-month-old tribal war that has killed more than 1,000 people, mostly civilians. No major fighting had been reported since Friday, when the government recaptured a rubber plantation 25 miles southwest of the capital. But the rebels maintained control of most of this Ohio-sized nation of 2.5 million West Africa. The rebels accuse Doe's administration of corruption, economic mismanagement and human rights abuses. Doe seized power in a bloody coup in 1980. A U.S.-arranged evacuation of Americans and other expatriates was scheduled for Sunday. An Air Guinea Boeing 737 was to make three trips from Monrovia to Abidjan, capital of neighboring Ivory Coast. Embassy officials said it appeared the vast majority of the nearly 1,500 Americans estimated to be in Liberia planned to stay. U.S. and British naval ships remained off the Liberian coast in case hostilities reached the capital and an emergency evacuation was necessary. Doe this week agreed to let Liberian religious leaders mediate the conflict. Moulton said the United States has been relaying messages between the church group and Taylor, who was educated in the United States. The council's request for American peacekeeping troops had been passed on to Washington, Moulton said. ``We are hoping for a positive response,'' he said. In Washington, State Department spokesman Dave Denny said he had no information on any such request. However, he read a statement expressing support for the peace effort. ``In our contacts with the government and the (rebel) Patriotic Front, we have urged them to negotiate a political settlement to the conflict to avoid further bloodshed.'' The church council statement said the government delegation to the peace talks will include Information Minister Emmanuel Bowier, Senate President Tambakai Jangaba and Deputy Foreign Minister Elbert Dunn. The statement did not identify the rebel delegation. The church group said its delegation would include Lutheran Bishop Ronald Diggs, Roman Catholic Archbishop Michael Francis and the Rev. Moulton, a Baptist. Government officials said troops had recaptured Harbel, where the U.S.-managed Firestone rubber plantation is located, after rebels took it earlier in the week. Rebel sources confirmed their forces had withdrawn from the plantation, which adjoins the country's international airport. The 120,000-acre rubber plantation, the world's largest, is operated by Bridgestone-Firestone Inc., an Akron, Ohio-based subsidiary of Japan's Bridgestone company. Government forces have been accused of killing hundreds of members of the Gio and Mano tribes, which are believed to support the rebels. The insurgents have been charged with killing many Krahn and Mandingo people, considered loyal to Doe, in revenge. Doe is a Krahn. Taylor began his insurgency Dec. 24, when a band of followers entered Liberia from Ivory Coast. His forces steadily advanced through the first four months of the war, pushing south toward the capital. The fighting sent more than 300,000 refugees fleeing to Monrovia and the countries of Ivory Coast, Guinea and Sierra Leone. Rebels captured the country's main iron ore mining installations and its chief port, Buchanan, 95 miles by road southeast of Monrovia. The U.S. warships off the coast will help only in an emergency evacuation, officials have said. The United States also has agreed to evacuate other foreign nationals. Liberia was founded in 1822 by descendants of freed American slaves and it became black Africa's first independent country in 1847.

DOC.HEAD: Youths Rampage During Leftist Protest in Paris
DOC.TEXT: Masked youths went on a rampage Saturday during a leftist protest march, smashing windows of banks, offices and a restaurant where right-wing extremists recently celebrated Adolf Hitler's birthday. No arrests or injuries were reported. The march was organized by a coalition of leftist groups to demand cancellation of the Third World's foreign debt and to protest racism. Police said about 2,000 people participated, but organizers claimed a turnout of 10,000. Witnesses said the youths who caused the trouble did not appear to be part of the main body of marchers. Their first target was Chez Jenny, a restaurant at the Place de la Republique where far-right groups have held several meetings over the years. They met there in April to mark the 101st anniversary of Hitler's birth.

DOC.HEAD: Leaders Say No Compromise in Protecting Gun Owners' Interests
With AM-Crime Bill, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the National Rifle Association assured members Saturday that recent legislative setbacks and declining membership won't weaken their determination to protect gun owners' interests. ``They say we must compromise. Our opponents define compromise as `We taketh, you giveth.' This is not compromise my friends. That is surrender,'' NRA First Vice President Richard D. Riley told the group's annual convention. The remarks drew applause from more than 1,000 members attending the second day of the three-day event at the Anaheim Convention Center. The convention comes at a crucial time in the NRA's history. Once considered politically invincible, the gun lobby has recently lost legislative battles in New Jersey, Maryland and California. Earlier this month, the NRA suffered one of its worst defeats when the U.S. Senate narrowly passed a ban on some assault rifles as part of an omnibus crime bill. The NRA rebounded by helping spark a filibuster on the bill, but both Democrats and Republicans said a compromise is still possible. The NRA also has lost an estimated 250,000 members over the last four years, and some of those remaining have either grumbled that the group has failed to work hard enough or has lost touch with the rank and file, overwhelmingly hunters and gun collectors. But Saturday's speeches signaled that the NRA, which still has 2.8 million members, will take a hard line rather than soften its position on handgun purchase waiting periods and assault rifle bans. Leaders called on members to stop bickering and mount a unified attack against what they described as misinformed media, liberal police chiefs and overly soft NRA members. Members agreed that the group must continue to fight. They said they fear that today's legislation banning assault rifles could be tomorrow's ban on the kinds of guns most NRA members actually have. ``It's just a matter of time that the next gun they'll be after is the shotgun,'' said William E. Smith of Owensboro, Ky. About 20,000 members of the 119-year-old organization and thousands of nonmembers came to the convention. In addition to speeches and workshops, there were vendors hawking everything from sunglasses to hunting rifles. Outgoing NRA President Joe Foss acknowledged in a speech that recent months have been difficult, but said the group is far from dead. ``We haven't lost everything,'' he said. ``What we've lost are some battles, but we'll win the war before it's all over with.''

DOC.HEAD: Organizers `Thrilled' at High Bidding at Belushi Memorial Auction
DOC.TEXT: Two sets of Blues Brothers suits brought $12,000 and a red satin jacket embroidered ``John'' fetched $1,400 Saturday at the John Belushi Memorial Auction. As a warm-up for the four-hour event, auctioneer Leslie Hindman offered a signed copy of ``Samurai Widow,'' a book by Judy Jacklin Belushi about the aftermath of her husband's death, and got $80 from among the audience of about 250 at a downtown auction house. The book retails for $21.95. ``If the whole sale goes like that, the charities will be delighted,'' Ms. Hindman said. It did, and they were. ``We're thrilled,'' said Mrs. Belushi, who donated all the items auctioned and estimated the event raised more than $100,000 for charity. ``I'm very happy.'' ``We underestimated virtually everything,'' said her fiance, movie producer Victor Pisano. ``It's unbelievable. We thought we might get $25,000.'' Belushi, a Chicago native, died of a drug overdose on March 5, 1982, at age 33. He was a favorite on NBC-TV's ``Saturday Night Live,'' and appeared in several movies, including ``The Blues Brothers,'' ``Continental Divide'' and ``Animal House.'' Pisano and Mrs. Belushi organized the auction to benefit the John Belushi Memorial Foundation, which will help aspiring actors in Chicago. The scholarship fund will be administered through the Chicago comedy troupe Second City, where the comedian got his start. One bidder, identifying himself only as ``Planet Hollywood, a dedicated follower of John Belushi,'' bid by telephone, and paid $12,000 for two complete suit sets worn by Belushi and Dan Aykroyd in ``The Blues Brothers.'' The bidder also paid thousands of dollars for various Blues Brothers paraphernalia and a red satin ``Second City'' jacket embroidered ``John.'' A 1965 Volvo owned by Belushi also was sold to an unidentified telephone bidder, for $4,000.

DOC.HEAD: Judy Garland Honored by Her Hometown
DOC.TEXT: Judy Garland's hometown honored the late actress Saturday with a parade that featured 13 Munchkins from the classic movie ``The Wizard of Oz'' and drew thousands of people. Under sunny skies, the Munchkins waved from a float in the design of a rainbow as high school bands played ``Somewhere Over the Rainbow,'' one of the memorable songs from the 1939 film. ``The weather broke right for Judy Garland's birthday,'' said John Kelsch, coordinator of the Judy Garland Festival in this northern Minnesota town of 8,000 people. Garland, who died in 1969, would have been 68 on Sunday. Margaret Pellegrini, who played one of the diminutive Munchkins in ``The Wizard of Oz,'' said she had fond memories of the movie and Garland. ``She was a great teen-ager,'' said the 66-year-old Glendale, Ariz., woman. ``Nobody had any idea when we were filming it that it would be such a classic.'' Lewis Croft, 71, of Shelley, Idaho, said he enjoyed reminiscing with his fellow former Munchkins. ``This is the first time I am seeing some of them, and it's great,'' Croft said. The festival continues through Tuesday. Other activities include a Judy Garland film festival and the opening of a museum featuring Garland memorabilia.

DOC.HEAD: Mexico, El Salvador Sign Pacts Easing 10 Years of Tension
DOC.TEXT: Mexico and El Salvador signed economic and cultural agreements Saturday in efforts to ease nearly 10 years of tension between the two governments over the Salvadoran civil war. The agreements restructure El Salvador's $77 million debt with Mexico and increase Mexican oil shipments to the Central American country by 50 percent. Salvadoran President Alfredo Cristiani told a news conference that El Salvador is behind in debt payments but gave few details on the restructuring program. He did say, however, the negotiations involve more Mexican investments in El Salvador. The increase in oil sales from 8,000 to 12,000 barrels a day comes under a 1981 pact under which Mexico and Venezuela sell oil to countries in the region at low interest with long-term credit. Other agreements that were signed Saturday cover cooperation in education, industrial development and radio and television. Relations between the two countries have been strained since 1980, when Mexico withdrew its ambassador to protest the killing of a Mexican journalist. In 1981, Mexico and France signed a joint declaration recognizing the leftist rebels in El Salvador as a political force. Mexico did not return its ambassador to San Salvador until 1985. The guerrillas continue to maintain a political office in Mexico and their leaders hold frequent news conferences in Mexico City. At a news conference, Cristiani said he was optimistic that a peace agreement ending the 10-year-old civil war in his country would be signed with the guerrillas by the end of this year. ``We believe that before September a cease-fire can be signed and that in the following months a lasting peace can be signed with the integration of the FMLN into the political life of the country as a political party and with full guarantees,'' he said. The FMLN is the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front, the umbrella group for five guerrilla factions fighting to overthrow the U.S.-backed government. Cristiani said the army could be reduced with the signing of a peace accord. ``If that is achieved, our army definitely will be able to be reduced considerably and the armed forces will be dedicated exclusively to safeguarding the integrity and sovereignty of El Salvador,'' he said. He did not indicate how many of the nation's 54,000 government troops could be demobilized. The government and guerrillas renewed talks in April, agreeing on an agenda for negotiations. More than 71,000 people, most of them civilians, have been killed in the war between leftist guerrillas and a succession of U.S.-backed governments.

DOC.HEAD: In Your Face, Springfield!
DOC.TEXT: In Saturday's competition, the contestants were better off without fire in the belly. The contestants: Battle Creek and Springfield, Mass. The weapons: flapjacks, cereal, doughnut holes, Pop Tarts, coffee, milk and orange drink. The final score: Battle Creek 38,753, Springfield 37,380. It was sweet revenge for the ``Cereal City,'' which reclaimed its crown Saturday after coming up empty in last year's annual breakfast battle. The victory was especially impressive since Springfield's population of 150,000 is almost three times Battle Creek's. ``It was a fantastic day; it was great,'' organizer Rick Royal said after 500 volunteers dished out 38,753 portions. The food was served for 3{ hours from a 2,500 foot-long table. ``It was an incredible effort for a town our size,'' Royal said. Battle Creek lost its title for the first time last year when Springfield, fed pancakes to 33,869 hungry residents, outdoing Battle Creek by 1,013 breakfasts. Royal, however, had a perfect alibi for last year's loss. In 1989, it was cold and rainy. This year, skies were sunny and temperatures high. Battle Creek is the home of Kellogg Co., Post and Ralston Purina Co. cereal plants. The city held its first free cereal breakfast in 1956 to celebrate the 50th anniversary of Kellogg's founding. In 1977, Springfield unsuccessfully challenged Battle Creek; the two cities began competing annually in 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Massive Contra Demobilization Launched On Eve of Deadline
DOC.TEXT: Calling it ``a farewell to arms,'' President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro on Saturday watched thousands of Contras line up to turn in their guns in a symbolic last push to meet a deadline for demobilization. Nicaraguan officials said the Contras might meet Sunday's deadline, but international organizations said it was unlikely. ``This emotional act puts an end to war in Nicaragua,'' Mrs. Chamorro told rebels assembled in the grassy square of El Almendro. ``Farewell to arms and war. We are now going to live in brotherhood.'' She spoke following a Mass offered by Roman Catholic Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo. But Santiago Murray, a representative of the Organization of American States' mission that provides aid to demobilized rebels, said the process will continue several days beyond the deadline. About 2,000 rebels were present at the weekend demobilization at El Almendro. Rebels with the U.S.-backed Contras began disarming May 7, but the process was suspended twice. Some 7,500 members of the 12,000-member guerrilla force remained to be demobilized Saturday. Murray said international organizations do not have the capacity to process more than 500 rebels a day, and bad weather was slowing down the disarmament at Almendro. At least six rebel commanders handed over their combat rifles to Mrs. Chamorro before a heavy thunderstorm sent people scattering for cover. Among the Contra leaders disarming were Jose Benito Bravo, the Contra chief of military intelligence. He stood in line with two thousand other rebels waiting to be processed by UN and OAS officials as a first step before returning to civilian life. Top Contra chief Israel Galeano, also known as Commander Franklin, told his assembled fighters that disarming is one of the ``concrete steps that are being taken toward democracy.'' He said demobilized rebels would now ``join in the efforts toward reconstruction.'' Despite the rain, UN peacekeeping troops proceeded to destroy the guerrilla's rifles using acetylene torches to cut through the metal. The demobilization process also requires rebels to turn in their combat fatigues, have their pictures taken and receive a medical examination.

DOC.HEAD: Actor Dudley Moore Picks Up Oxford Degree 32 Years Late
DOC.TEXT: Actor Dudley Moore on Saturday picked up his two diplomas from Oxford University _ 32 years late. The 55-year-old actor attended the Magdalen College graduation ceremonies and collected his Master of Arts and Bachelor of Music degrees. Moore said he ``forgot'' to pick up the diplomas after finishing classes in 1958. ``I just didn't seem to get round to it, but if I did have a reason I don't think I'm going to explain why,'' said Moore, who starred in films including ``Arthur'' and ``10.'' The actor said the visit to Oxford, 52 miles northwest of London, brought back memories of his university days when he studied the organ. ``It just reminded me how comatose I was when I came here,'' he said. ``I don't think I used my time here as I wanted to. I wasn't working as hard as I might have done, but I think that is everybody's complaint when they are here.'' After the ceremony Moore, and his wife, Brogan, attended a garden party at Magdalen College. The actor was also scheduled to give an organ recital in the college chapel.

DOC.HEAD: Kidnapped Peorian's Employer Optimistic
DOC.TEXT: An American miner kidnapped by South American guerrillas will be released, and plans to continue working in Ecuador, his employer said. Jeff Fino said he expects the guerrillas to honor their word to return Scott Heimdal of Peoria after receiving $60,000 in ransom Friday. ``These are people who are committed to their word,'' Fino said in a telephone interview from Ecuador with the Peoria Journal Star published Saturday. ``To these people, kidnapping is a business, not a crime.'' Fino also expects Heimdal to be back at his job. ``Scott's been telling his kidnappers that when he's released he's going back to work in the mine,'' said Fino, a 39-year-old Pennsylvania native who moved to Ecuador three years ago to work a gold mine. Heimdal was taken during an April 28 ambush in an Ecuadoran jungle that left one man dead and another seriously wounded. His family raised Heimdal's ransom through a public appeal capped by a flurry of donations in the last few days. His parents, Roy and Marge Heimdal, wired the $60,000 to a bank in Quito, Ecuador, just before a deadline of noon Friday. Fino said the group has promised never again to harass employees of Iminco, Fino's mining company. He said they have also promised that no other guerrilla groups will harass the company's operations. The kidnappers, members of a Colombian group known as the Popular Liberation Army, have made similar promises in the past and kept them, he said. ``Negotiations are proceeding well,'' he said. ``We have excellent cooperation from many different agencies, people and organizations. We have everything we feel we need.'' Although he declined to identify the U.S. agencies involved, a spokeswoman at U.S. Rep. Robert H. Michel's office said FBI and State Department officials were sent to the area. The Controlled Risk Group of London, a kidnap consulting firm that grew out of Lloyd's of London insurance company in the 1960s, has also been retained by Fino. Fino pointed out that the harshly worded demand for ransom never states specifically the guerrillas will kill Heimdal if the ransom is not raised. However, Heimdal's mother said the kidnappers threatened to ``show us where his body is'' if the ransom is not raised. Scott Heimdal's parents were resting Saturday, according to a family member who answered their home phone. They hope to fly to Ecuador to meet their son if and when he is released. Fino said that since the kidnapping the mine's operations have shut down except for maintenance work.

DOC.HEAD: Dominican Opposition to Visit Congress
DOC.TEXT: Opposition officials will travel to the United States early next week for meetings with members of Congress on alleged fraud in May 16 elections, a party official said Saturday. There is still no clear winner in the race. Preliminary election results showed President Joaquin Balaguer of the Social Christian Reformist party with 669,863 votes and the Dominican Liberation Party's Juan Bosch with 647,969 votes. Bosch claimed there was widespread electoral fraud, and the Central Electoral Council is undergoing a review of tally sheets at each polling district to verify the results. Vicente Bengoa, an official with Bosch's party, said the delegation will also travel to the Carter Center in Atlanta. Former President Jimmy Carter was one of 30 international observers who witnessed the election. It is unclear exactly when the delegation will arrive in the United States or how long it will stay. Balaguer and Bosch, both in their 80s, have dominated Dominican politics for the last three decades.

DOC.HEAD: Defunct Wild West Village Finally Bites The Dust
LaserPhoto BF1
DOC.TEXT: A ghost town high above the city disappeared Saturday when Fentier Village, an amusement park billed as ``where the Old West comes east,'' was disassembled and auctioned off. Carved into a mountaintop 1,500 feet up, the frontier town replica was conceived by Ned Fenton, an insurance and real estate agent who realized his dream of building an amusement park near this far western New York state town. Fenton died of cancer six months ago. Fentier Village, opened in 1966, was a three-tiered frontier town connected by cable car and steps made of railroad ties. Visitors also traveled through the park via stagecoach, a 1{-mile train ride or on horseback. Along Main Street, with its requisite barber shop, bank and hotel, good guys outdrew bad guys four times a day in staged shootouts that ended with stuntmen _ often Fenton's sons _ ``dying'' in dramatic falls from second-story porches. The park also featured Silver Dollar Ballroom, where such entertainers as Hank Williams Jr. and Frank Sinatra Jr. appeared, and a cinema that showed silent films. But three years later, the park closed when the state condemned the parking lots and first tier at the base of the mountain to build a superhighway. And the Code of the West didn't mean fire and building codes. The buildings, maintained by Fenton in hopes of reopening the park some day, failed to meet safety standards. They and their furnishings were sold. Saturday's auction drew about 500 people and raised at least $70,000. The high-price item was a truck carrying a calliope which went for $8,600. An old nickelodian that prompted spirited bidding brought $7,000. Other items included a huge chandelier, two coin-operated ``shoot-'em-up'' robotic cowboys, a life-sized fiberglass horse and a number of horse-drawn wagons, carriages and sleighs. The park was on a mountain called Roundtop that, legend has it, the Seneca Indians used as a burial ground. Fenton's sons envision developing the scenic property into a year-round resort with skiing, horseback riding, restaurants and possibly a hotel. Some came to the auction to get a last look at a part of their past. ``The reason we came up here today is we came up here when we were kids,'' said Carol Waldrip of nearby Olean. ``It's really kind of sad for us to see all this stuff go.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor Wins Democratic-Farmer-Labor Endorsement
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Gov. Rudy Perpich crowned a week that started with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit by winning his party's endorsement Saturday for an unprecedented fourth term. Perpich, 61, won the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party's blessing on the fourth ballot, defeating his former commerce commissioner, Mike Hatch. Needing 60 percent of the vote, Perpich and Lt. Gov. Marlene Johnson received about 64.4 percent to about 34.4 percent for Hatch and his running mate, former state Sen. Emily Anne Staples. Gorbachev's historic stop in Minnesota was on Perpich's mind when he accepted the endorsement. The Soviet president ``came to Minnesota to gain a heartland experience, to see how Americans live,'' Perpich said. ``He saw a state that works.'' Hatch, who served as Perpich's commerce commissioner from 1983 through 1989, was rejected by delegates of a party he chaired from 1980 to 1982. The endorsement was a defeat for supporters of legalized abortion, whose pro-choice position is the party's official stance. Perpich opposes abortion and Hatch is an abortion rights advocate. Hatch, 42, called the delegates' decision a personal disappointment but not a major setback for his campaign. He vowed to continue on to the Sept. 11 primary. ``Voters want a new governor. ... If this party is not the agent of change, it may be a victim of change,'' Hatch said. Perpich disagreed and said abortion will not be as big an issue in the primary election as it was in the endorsement contest. ``There's a lot of hard work that has to be done. I think he's thrown his Sunday punch and we're still standing,'' Perpich said of his opponent. Four Republicans are seeking the nomination of their party, which will choose a candidate next weekend.

DOC.HEAD: City Loses More Than 1 Million Gallons After Water Main Break
DOC.TEXT: More than 1 million gallons of water gushed for hours from a broken main line in this coastal community that already is in the throes of a drought. The line broke early Friday and water flooded for about three hours before city workers shut off the flow. The spilled water was 8 feet deep near a downtown highway, said Charlie Hench, a spokesman for the California Transportation Department. A highway improvement project is under way in the area and Hench said a concrete support collapsed beneath the pipe, causing it to break. Traffic was unaffected by the spill. City officials said the wasted water was enough to meet the needs of 10 people for a year. They said earth eroded away by rushing water would have to be replaced before the main could be repaired. Effects of the water loss on the city's estimated 70,000 residents could not be determined. City Engineer Bruce Burnworth and other city officials could not be reached Saturday by telephone. Southern California, including Santa Barbara, has been beset by a water shortage this summer. The City Council declared a drought emergency in February. Until new, long-term sources of water can be developed, city officials have imposed stringent water rationing measures on residents, including a ban on outdoor watering.

DOC.HEAD: 17 Hurt in Blast at Historic Military Site in London
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 14 grafs to UPDATE number of wounded, details on explosion. Pickup pvs 11th graf, `The Honorable...'
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded Saturday night outside a 250-year-old military building in central London, injuring 17 people, most of whom were at a birthday party inside, officials said. Police superintendent David Smith said the blast at the barracks of the Honorable Artillery Company in City Road, just north of the City financial district, ``is being treated at top-level security as a terrorist attack.'' He said the bomb damaged the building known as Armory House, built in 1735, which is part of the army reserve unit's barracks complex. There was no immediate claim of responsibility but suspicion fell on the outlawed Irish Republican Army, which has extended its fight to end British rule in Northern Ireland to the British mainland. David Dalton, assistant general manager of St. Bartholomew's Hospital, said the 12 women and five men were injured by flying glass from shattered windows. He said none of the victims suffered serious injuries. Tom Parker, 21, a Canadian student at the London School of Economics, said about 30 students were inside at a 21st birthday party. ``We were all standing at the bar upstairs when there was a loud bang. People were screaming and shouting and then they calmed down and some of the older people started helping the injured,'' Parker said. Chief Inspector Malcolm Hines of the city police force said the explosion detonated on the roof of the building. ``There was no warning,'' he said. Residents half a mile from the scene said they heard the blast. The London Ambulance Service said five ambulances rushed to the scene. Military and explosive experts were at the scene and surrounding roads were blocked off, Parker said. In stepped up attacks outside Northern Ireland, IRA gunmen killed one soldier and wounded two others in the northern England city of Lichfield June 1 and have killed 14 people on the European continent since 1978, most of them British military personnel. The Honorable Artillery Company is part of Britain's volunteer Territorial Army, a 80,000-member reserve force for the professional full-time army. The company, which specializes in reconnaissance and gunnery, claims to be the oldest military body in Britain and was originally a company of archers granted a charter by King Henry VIII in 1537. Their main object was the defense of London but the members also fought in foreign wars and served with the fleet against the Spanish Armada, which was defeated in its attempt to invade England in 1588.

DOC.HEAD: Tanker Blast Kills At Least Two
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 24 grafs to CORRECT that one cutter standing by, sted two; move up comment on possibility of ship breaking up; ADD that current also a positive factor; ADD that captain's wife, two kids were also on ship; picks up 22nd graf, `The 17 ...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos HT5,9; LaserColor HT6
DOC.TEXT: Explosions and fire rocked a Norwegian oil tanker in the Gulf of Mexico Saturday, killing at least two, but authorities said it was unlikely the ship would foul Texas beaches with a massive oil spill. Two crewmen were confirmed dead in the 1 a.m. explosion and, authorities said two others were missing and presumed dead. Of the crew of 41, 17 crew members were injured, none seriously, officials said. The hunt for the missing crewmen was called off Saturday evening after boats and airplanes were unable to find any trace of them. Coast Guard Chief Petty Officer Rich Muller said the missing men were probably still aboard the ship. The 853-foot supertanker Mega Borg was hauling about 38 million gallons of light crude oil when the first blast occurred, 57 miles southeast of Galveston, the Coast Guard said. The flames shot hundreds of feet high from the ship's air vents as thick, black smoke _ which could be seen from 40 miles away _ curled from the ship's aft section. The fire continued to rage out of control late Saturday night, as two fireboats sprayed jets of water on the flames. A Coast Guard cutter stood by, and a third fireboat was en route. The battle was expected to last all night, more reinforcements hired by the vessel's owner were expected to arrive Sunday morning, Muller said. ``There'll be at least 10 vessels that will be going out to work on the salvage operation,'' he said. He said the cost of the firefighting effort was being covered by the owner. The Mega Borg could break up and sink, Muller said, but that was considered a remote possibility. He said officials were unsure how much damage the fire was doing to the ship. ``We've not seen any indication that the vessel will sink or break apart,'' he added. The first explosion occurred in the engine room while the 15-year-old tanker was transferring its shipment to the Italian tanker Framura. The Mega Borg had transferred 70,000 barrels of its 980,000 barrels of crude oil when the blast occurred, Coast Guard Capt. Tom Greene said at a news conference in Galveston. ``We don't know what caused the spark or the fire or whatever, but there were explosions and while our helicopters were on the scene they witnessed another explosion _ so it's a pretty hot fire,'' Petty Officer George Wilson said earlier in Houston. Two more explosions occurred shortly before 2 p.m. Saturday, said Muller. Greene said about 7,000 gallons of crude oil or ship fuel spread on the water, creating an oil sheen about 11 miles long and a quarter-mile wide. Coast Guard officials speculated that the fuel poured into the water from hoses used to transfer the oil to the Italian tanker, or that it poured out the top of the tanker as the fire heated up the oil and caused it to expand. ``If all goes well, I really don't expect much more pollution than is out there,'' Greene said. ``We don't expect any of the oil to reach the Texas coast,'' said Ensign Larry Meredith of the Coast Guard's Marine Safety Office in Galveston. ``It will mix with natural ocean water and _ if nature takes its course _ evaporate. Being 50, 60 miles off the coast, we just expect it to evaporate.'' In addition, the current was running parallel to the coast, instead of towards it. Greene said the biggest fear was that the fire, which apparently was being fed by burning engine oil or lubricating oil, might spread to three cargo tanks near the engine room. The three tanks hold 360,000 barrels, or roughly 15 million gallons of the light crude. Greene said even if oil spilled, there would be no disaster like the 11 million-gallon Exxon Valdez spill in 1989. More than 1,100 miles of Alaskan shoreline were soiled by the spill of heavy crude. The Mega Borg's shipment is light crude, which would disperse much more rapidly than heavy crude, he said, adding that the Mega Borg is much smaller than the Exxon Valdez. Following the blast, the Mega Borg's captain and first mate escaped and were taken aboard the Coast Guard cutter Cushing. The other surviving crew members, the captain's wife and his two children were taken to Freeport aboard the commercial vessel Patricia M. The 17 injured crew members were taken to Brazosport Memorial Hospital in Lake Jackson, where two were hospitalized. The other 15 were treated for smoke inhalation and released, said nursing supervisor Linda Runnels. The hospitalized crew members were in stable condition; one underwent surgery for an injured tendon in his left arm and the other suffered a leg injury, Ms. Runnels said. Coast Guard officials said they didn't know refinery or refineries the oil was destined for. The Houston-Galveston area is home to several major refineries. Greene said the fire could burn out of control for two days, and authorities prepared for a worst-case scenario, putting together response teams consisting of Environmental Protection Agency officials, the Coast Guard Atlantic Strike Team and other state and federal agencies. As a precaution, a high-seas boom to contain oil was being brought in from Mobile, Ala., Greene said. Officials also requested a plane with a special infrared detectors so authorities could track an oil spill at night. The Mega Borg was coming from Palanca, Angola. Its next port of call, after Galveston, was scheduled to be Aruba. The tanker's U.S. agent is Biehl and Co. of Galveston. A man answering the telephone there Saturday said the company had no comment. The tanker is operated by Mosvolds Shipping of Farsund, Norway. Managing Director Geir Larsen said his company owns a little less than 50 percent of the tanker, through the K-S Mega Borg investment group. He said other owners are private investors, whom he refused to identify. Larsen said he knew of no previous problems with the ship. The crew was from the Philippines and the officers are Indian; the captain is C.M. Mahidhara, Larsen said.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Leaders Reach Accord on Quebec Status
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 16 grafs to UPDATE with accord signed; Bourassa reax; ADDS background on impact of accord. Pickup 14th graf pvs, `Quebec refused...'
DOC.TEXT: Canada's leaders signed a tentative deal Saturday night to rescue a flagging constitutional accord that would grant special status to French-speaking Quebec. Newfoundland's premier, Clyde Wells, said he remained dissatisfied with the compromise but may submit it for a popular referendum in his province. However, Wells signed the agreement with the nine other provincial premiers in a nationally televised public session Saturday night. ``This is a happy day for Canada,'' declared Prime Minister Brian Mulroney before signing the document. The agreement was worked out in Ottawa at the end of the seventh day of private talks aimed at persuading holdout provinces to approve the package. Even if ratified, the constitutional amendment recognizing Quebec as a ``distinct society'' clause would have no immediate practical effect. However, it would oblige the Supreme Court to consider the province's distinctiveness when considering specific laws challenged under the constitution. It is also a symbol of enormous significance to French-speaking Quebecers. ``It was a great exercise in nation building,'' said Ontario Premier David Peterson after the accord was achieved. ``There was blood in the floor, but it was common blood. But Wells declared, ``I am not approving of this particular accord.'' He said he may submit it to a popular or legislative referendum in his province before the June 23 ratification deadline. New Brunswick Premier Frank McKenna, who had been another holdout until the latest talks, called the compromise ``the best deal possible.'' Quebec Premier Robert Bourassa initially boycotted the talks Saturday after refusing to discuss any more changes in the clause that would recognize Quebec as a ``distinct society.'' However, later in the day, he returned to the talks. The tentative agreement would leave the distinct-society clause unaltered but ask constitutional experts to prepare a legal opinion on how it would affect the country's rights charter. Bourassa said of the final compromise: ``This is not affecting the integrity of the Meech Lake accord. We are quite satisfied that our objectives are fulfilled.'' In announcing the agreement, Peterson said it must still be approved by the legislatures of Newfoundland and New Brunswick as well as a third holdout, Manitoba. Mulroney convened the 10 provincial leaders for the private talks because they face a June 23 deadline for ratification of the amendment to the 1982 Canadian constitution. Quebec refused to sign the constitution, saying it did not take the province's distinct French character into consideration. In an effort to win Quebec's support, the amendment, known as the Meech Lake accord, contains the clause that designates Quebec a ``distinct society.'' The other points in Meech Lake include expanding the provinces' powers to opt out of some federal-provincial spending programs and a new constitutional amending formula. Bourassa of Quebec has made no direct threats regarding separatism if the accord is not approved, but nationalism is on the rise in the province and there is a growing sentiment for either separation or some sort of independence-association arrangement with the rest of Canada. Canada has 25 million residents, but one-fourth of them live in Quebec. In 1987, Mulroney and the 10 premiers signed a five-point agreement for the Meech Lake constitutional amendment and set a three-year deadline for ratification. In the interim, governments changed in Newfoundland, Manitoba and New Brunswick and the new premiers reneged on the signatures of their predecessors. Quebec had insisted the accord must be passed as is and that other concerns worrying some of the premiers, such as Senate reform, can be discussed at a future constitutional conference.

DOC.HEAD: Coast Guard Says No More Fuel Leaking From Sunken Tugboat
With AM-Tanker Blast, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Plans to raise a tugboat that sank in the St. Johns River were postponed Saturday night, but only after workers made sure no more diesel fuel was leaking from the 800-ton vessel, officials said. The Captain Bill, which spilled about 1,000 gallons of diesel fuel when it sank Friday in Jacksonville, was rescheduled for raising Sunday with two cranes mounted on barges, U.S. Coast Guard Lt. Lynn Woods said. Coast Guard officials and representatives of Crowley Towing and Transportation Co., which contracted the 117-foot tug, said there was no reason to rush because the disabled tug is mired outside a main shipping channel and is no longer leaking fuel. ``The decision was to proceed with caution, do it right and safely, since it was not impeding navigation and since the diesel fuel was not leaking any longer,'' said Lucille Lane, director of public relations for Crowley. ``The fuel is contained. Everything at this point is secure.'' Even so, small quantities of engine oil from the vessel were still bubbling to the river's surface Saturday, Woods said. The Coast Guard has classified the spill as minor, but that could change if a significant amount of the 53,000 gallons of diesel fuel remaining on board begins to leak, Woods said. A fuel tank rupture during efforts to raise the vessel was not considered a major threat, he said. The spilled fuel was cleaned up using absorbent pads and a floating skimmer. Containment booms were placed around the boat. Plans call for pumping the remaining fuel from the tug after it is raised, then towing the vessel to the nearby Crowley dock or a dry dock so it can be examined to determine what caused it to sink, Woods said. The Captain Bill had been en route to Guantanamo Bay, Cuba, taking a 400-foot barge loaded with sand to be used in construction, when a device used to secure the barge to the tug broke, Woods said. The tug was heading back to the Crowley docks when it sank.

DOC.HEAD: Black Priest Elected a Bishop in Los Angeles Episcopal Diocese
Laserphoto LA3
DOC.TEXT: The first black Episcopal bishop in the Los Angeles diocese was elected Saturday by clergy and lay delegates. A two-thirds majority of 180 clergy and 400 lay delegates elected the Rev. Chester L. Talton, 48, as assistant bishop on the fifth ballot. There were six other candidates. ``I'm a little stunned, yet I am very pleased,'' said Talton, rector of St. Philip's Episcopal Church in New York City's Harlem neighborhood. ``I feel a real nudging toward the Diocese of Los Angeles from the Holy Spirit,'' Talton said. ``I look forward to working with laity and clergy to address the many issues the church faces today.'' Talton's duties will be to assist diocesan Bishop Frederick H. Borsch in overseeing the six-county diocese, which has 80,000 members in 150 congregations. ``I respect him for his wisdom, spirituality and love for others,'' Borsch said of Talton. Talton has led the 500-member St. Philip's Church, one of the largest congregations of black Episcopalians, since 1985. A native of Eldorado, Ariz., he grew up in Oakland. Talton received a master of divinity degree from the Episcopal Church Divinity School of the Pacific in Berkeley. He will succeed the Right Rev. Oliver B. Garver Jr., who retires June 30 to serve as chaplain of the Harvard School in Studio City. The diocese contains Los Angeles, Orange, Santa Barbara, Ventura and San Bernadino counties and part of Riverside County.

DOC.HEAD: Flooding Threat Prompts Central Ohio Evacuations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERT 1 graf after penultimate graf, `Authorities said ...' to UPDATE with second man missing in Ohio. Pick up last graf, `The storms ...'
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains forced up to 10,000 people from their homes, and National Guard troops hoisted sandbags on an earthen wall at Buckeye Lake to keep the water from spilling over. Authorities said the evacuees in Licking County were forced to leave their homes temporarily because of the flood threat. The National Weather Service issued a flash flood warning, citing possible dam failure at the man-made lake. Flooding also was reported farther south in Perry County. County Disaster Services Coordinator Dorothy Sidwell said residents were evacuated from sections of New Lexington and Crooksville, but the number of people affected was not known. In Pennsylvania, a fast-moving storm system drenched some of the state's central and eastern counties Saturday, leaving behind pockets of darkness from power outages and barns burned and chimneys damaged by bolts of lightning. The thunderstorms crossed the state about 50 mph, said weather service meteorologists in Pittsburgh. About 10,000 households in Pittsburgh were without power for little over an hour Friday night because of high winds, officials said. In Bethlehem, electrical storms knocked out power to more than 45,000 people on Friday and Saturday. In Licking County, the evacuations began shortly before dawn but people were allowed to return by afternoon. The weather service said 2 to 4 inches of rain fell overnight in central and north central Ohio. About 50 Ohio National Guard soldiers helped volunteers reinforce the wall with sandbags and assisted with evacuations of about 2,000 residents of the town of Buckeye Lake, about 30 miles east of Columbus. Gov. Richard Celeste visited Buckeye Lake after declaring a state of emergency in the county. He said he would ask President Bush to declare Licking County a federal disaster area. Licking County Sheriff Gerry Billy said officials took steps to reduce pressure on the weakened earthen wall by opening floodgates on the spillway at Buckeye Lake. Water levels had reached the top when rains ended at midmorning. Flooding also forced the evacuation of about 3,000 people in south Newark living near the Licking River and campers at a racetrack, authorities said. As many as 5,000 other Licking County residents may have been displaced temporarily, said Randy Spiker, deputy director of the county disaster services agency. Buckeye Lake covers more than 3,000 acres in portions of three central Ohio counties. The man-made lake was created in the 19th century to hold water for the Erie Canal. The lake reaches depths of eight to 10 feet, especially along the 4-mile-long retaining wall, which is about 12 feet tall, Ohio Department of Natural Resources officials said. Only sandbags, stacked two-deep, kept water from lapping over the top of the earthen wall and into homes whose porches opened onto it. Spiker said water from the lake was being released into the Licking River. ``We've got monitors watching it downstream, and it does not seem to be causing any trouble at this time,'' he said. Twelve miles of Interstate 70 were closed for a short while, said Beverly Schell, a highway patrol dispatcher. Some exits were blocked to all but emergency traffic. The deck of a bridge on U.S. 40 east of Jacksontown was washed away, Spiker said. In addition to Licking County, Celeste declared a state of emergency in Perry County, where flooding prompted evacuations in New Lexington and Crooksville. Elsewhere around Ohio, tornadoes and thunderstorms triggered localized flooding. There were no reports of major damage, but a Wayne County man was missing after falling from a dam. Authorities said Guy Over of West Salem was missing and feared drowned after falling into the rain-swollen Apple Creek stream in Wooster. Another man was reported missing after apparently falling into the Licking River while floating on an inner tube Saturday night near St. Louisville, said Steve Prince, a Licking County sheriff's dispatcher. The man's identity was not immediately released. The storms Friday night and Saturday morning followed a round of heavy rain that caused urban and small-stream flooding early in the morning and knocked out power to thousands of electrical customers.

DOC.HEAD: Founder Quits; Attorney General Probe Focuses On Whether He Took Money
DOC.TEXT: The state attorney general is investigating allegations that a founder of a newspaper sold by the homeless took money after resigning, a spokesman said Saturday. New York Newsday and the Daily News, quoting unidentified sources, reported Saturday that employees of Street News have told the attorney general's office as much as $250,000 is unaccounted for. Edward Barbini, a spokesman for Attorney General Robert Abrams, said the office had received reports that co-founder Hutchinson Persons, who resigned Wednesday, may have taken money from the paper. ``We're investigating those charges,'' Barbini said. ``The attorney general believes there were people getting helped by this,'' the spokesman said. ``It would be a shame if Hutchinson Persons was pre-eminent among them.'' Street News spokesman Jeffrey Sussman said Persons had submitted his resignation, but said he had no evidence of misappropriation of funds. Sussman told the News that the allegations were ``rumors fabricated by ex-employees. ... You'd have to be pretty stupid to take money with the whole world watching you.'' A message left on Persons' answering machine was not immediately returned, but he and others have said repeatedly that those who started the paper six months ago worked for little or no money until he accepted a salary of less than $50,000 early this year. Wendy Koltun, the paper's co-founder who left Street News in January in a disagreement over Persons' management style, said she was confident the allegations were false. ``He wrote me a note saying, `All I want is the shirt on my back,''' she said. ``He left for the good of the paper so it could continue,'' she said. ``The media made him very controversial and he realized this. He realized that if the paper was going to survive and do what we had originally intended to do, he would have to leave.'' Street News began publishing in November, and has been sold on streets and subways by homeless people who keep 50 cents of the 75 cents for each sale. Persons said in an interview several weeks ago that he had considered quitting the paper ``about 20 or 30 times'' because of all the stress it caused. Fellow staff members of the paper accused him of ``erratic and irresponsible behavior,'' including sudden firings.

DOC.HEAD: Lieutenant Governor Candidate Speaks at Klan Leader's Home
DOC.TEXT: An ex-Nazi seeking the Republican nomination for lieutenant governor spoke to about 100 people Saturday outside the home of a Ku Klux Klan leader. Ralph Forbes, in a runoff battle against black businessman Kenneth ``Muskie'' Harris, is known as a white supremacist and Klan sympathizer. In a May 29 primary, Forbes won 46 percent of the vote to 36 percent for Harris, but failed to win the 50 percent necessary to prevent a runoff, which is set for Tuesday. Republican leaders have endrosed Harris. ``I say the white race is supremely stupid because we've allowed our country to get stolen from us,'' Forbes told reporters before addressing a crowd of about 100 people who gathered outside the home of Thom Robb, a grand wizard of the Klan. Robb was hosting his semiannual Patriots' Day picnic. He said about 25 percent of the crowd at his home in rural Boone County were Klan members. Forbes told a story of an eagle that flew into a barnyard of chickens and turkeys and didn't know his real heritage. The chickens and turkeys looked down on the eagle, then ``black crows'' came down and stole the eagle's food, Forbes said. A storm erupted and the eagle opened its wings and was able to brave the storm, he said. Forbes said he identifies with the eagle. ``Now is the time to face the storm,'' Forbes said. ``When we realize we are not chickens, we are not turkeys, we are American eagles, we are going to rise above the storm and we are going to beat this thing.'' Robb said he personally backed Forbes for the GOP nomination. ``The Klan doesn't endorse anybody, but I personally am for him,'' Robb said.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Dismisses Felony Battery Charge in Schoolyard Scuffle
DOC.TEXT: A 10-year-old boy charged with aggravated battery for allegedly flattening the nose of a schoolmate who called him ``fatso'' walked out of court a free child after a judge dismissed the case. Juvenile Court Judge Lawrence Korda dropped the charge Friday against Bobby Woods after a prosecutor told him the only witness to the schoolyard scuffle last August now says the other boy started the fight. Bobby's lawyer, Paul Stark, was elated but still angry that prosecutors ever bothered to pursue the case. ``This matter should have been resolved in a principal's office, not in a court of law,'' Stark said. Bobby said Khalid Fathallah, also 9 at the time, and another boy called him ``fatso,'' said ``oink oink'' and tried to kick him on the playground of Plantation Park Elementary School. Bobby, 5 feet tall and 101 pounds, responded by punching Khalid in the nose. Khalid's parents, Hassib and Vicki Fathallah of Plantation, said their son's nose was broken. They pressed charges after Bobby's father, Nolan Woods, refused to pay more than half the medical bills. Assistant State Attorney Susan Aramony said the other boy gave a sworn statement to Stark backing Bobby's claim that Khalid started the fight.

Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, responding to concerns that short-range nuclear missiles could leak plutonium, is ordering Air Force bombers to stop carrying older missiles until safety studies are completed. Cheney said in a statement Friday he was taking the step as ``a precaution.'' The directors of three U.S. nuclear weapons laboratories called for the withdrawal of the weapons during congressional testimony last month. They suggested there was a remote possibility the weapons could leak plutonium in an accident. The missiles are known as the Short-Range Attack Missile-A, or SRAM-As, and are carried aboard the nation's 372 deployed B-52, B-1B and FB-111 bombers. The Air Force has said that 1,500 of the weapons were produced between 1971 and 1975, but the current number deployed is classified.

President Bush is pledging that a united Germany will not threaten the Soviet Union but says he and West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl have ``no specific formula'' to ensure that. Bush and Kohl, after meeting Friday evening, continued to insist on keeping a unified Germany in NATO _ something the Soviet Union strongly opposes _ and Bush said they talked about ``an expanded role'' for the Western alliance in the future. ``We also agree that the Soviets have understandable interests in all of this but we did not try to fashion some compromise at this juncture,'' he said in the Rose Garden where he and Kohl took questions from reporters. Bush said further consultations will take place before and after the July meeting of allied leaders in London.

A former Army sergeant accused of selling NATO's nuclear defense secrets to East bloc governments speaks four languages, has an amazing memory and has shown no remorse since he confessed, an FBI agent testified. U.S. Magistrate Elizabeth Jenkins on Friday ordered Roderick James Ramsay, 28, held until a bond hearing Tuesday on a charge of conspiracy to gather or deliver defense information to aid a foreign government. Ramsay's arrest Thursday night came only a day after his former Army supervisor and classified documents manager, Clyde Lee Conrad, 43, was convicted of treason in a West German court and sentenced to life in prison. FBI agents say Conrad masterminded an espionage ring that sold highly sensitive information to Hungarian and Czechoslovakian intelligence agents, who eventually passed it to the Soviet KGB.

A federal judge rejected Manuel Noriega's claim that the United States has no jurisdiction to indict him on charges he trafficked drugs as Panama's leader. In a second blow Friday to Noriega's legal defense, a co-defendant in a parallel Tampa indictment named the ousted Panamanian dictator as a ``silent partner'' in a drug ring. In Miami, U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler rejected defense claims that Noriega had immunity for his actions and could not be prosecuted for activities outside the United States. In Tampa, Panamanian jeweler Enrique A. ``Kiki'' Pretelt admitted in a plea agreement that he helped launder drug proceeds with two convicted Tampa drug smugglers, according to a 10-page plea agreement.

Sheriff's deputies made their first arrest of a record retailer under a federal judge's ruling deeming a rap record by 2 Live Crew obscene. The band's leader said his record label will help pay legal fees. The group performed its sexually explicit material live in Miami Beach early today. Authorities did not interfere with the 45-minute show. The audience cheered when band leader Luther Campbell shouted vulgarities about Gov. Bob Martinez and Broward County Sheriff Nick Navarro, whose deputies Friday arrested E-C Records owner Charles Freeman, 31, on misdemeanor charges of distributing obscene material. The deputies burst into the store after an undercover agent bought the group's recording ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be,'' which U.S. District Judge Jose Gonzalez ruled Wednesday is obscene. The ruling did not affect live performances.
